title: mum who couldnt fit through
story: Mum who couldnt fit through turnstile sheds half her body weight thanks to new dietAmy Woolliscroft, from Hatton in Derbyshire, wore a size  at her biggest and hated her reflection, but shes now dropped from st b to st lbAmy Woolliscroft when she was  years old Image: PA Real LeByZoe ForseyFeatures EditorSusan Clark:,  Jan | commentsWhen Amy Woolliscroft went to watch a Derby County football match with her dad as a teenager, she was looking forward to a fun day out cheering on her favourite team. But she was absolutely horried when she couldnapost fit through the turnstile. Someone saw me struggling and called out that they’d open the gates which was so embarrassing, because I was just too big to get through the turnstiles, she said. Everyone around us saw and heard it. The traumatic event stayed with her for years, but she was still unable to shed the weight and hated how she looked. But now at the age of , Amy, from Hatton in Derbyshire, has shed an incredible st lb - dropping from st b to st lb. The day nursery manager, who is mum to six-year-old Noah, said: I wanted to make sure I was here for my son and that I was fit enough to run around with him. That was why I decided to do something about my weight. I always knew one day I would lose it. I just never knew when. Amy wore a size  at her heaviest and hated seeing her reflection, but was finally shocked into action by her festive photos from Christmas  following months of comfort eating after a relationship ended.Amy, who stands at ft in, had a body mass indexused to gauge a healthy weight, of  - compared to the NHS healthy range of . to . - making her dangerously obese.With the support of her best friend, Lucy, , she joined a diet club online, started exercising in earnest and watched her waistline shrink until she felt like she had a brand new identity. Now wearing a size - with a healthy BMI of ., she said: “My real friends will tell me, aposYou were beautul then and you are beautul now.apos Some people have said, ‘I always knew there was a beautul face in there.’ But I’ve not done this for anyone , I’ve done it for me.  “I’ve always been the ‘Big Girl.’ I wasn’t bullied at school, because I hung out with the popular girls, but when they all had boyfriends I didn’t. “And I always hated PE and having to get changed in front of other people at school. “Throughout my le, when Iaposve looked in the mirror, Iaposve hated what I saw, as I just didn’t love myself. Remembering how she and her brother were fussy eaters and refused to eat vegetables as children, Amy also realises now that her parents splitting up when she was nine accentuated her already unhealthy relationship with food. She said: “My brother and I just ate crisps, potatoes, bread and sweets. “After my parents split up, we lived with my dad and I remember stepping onto the scales in the bathroom for the first time when I was  and being horried because I weighed st. It really hit home, because I knew my dad weighed st, so not that much more than me. ” After leaving school, Amy trained in childcare at college and landed a job at a local nursery, where she worked for  years. Then, seven years ago, she moved to the nursery where she works now, saying: I am very determined. “Once I have made my mind up to do something, then I don’t lose that focus.” And while she spent half of  comfort eating, after splitting up with Noahaposs dad in the May, she soon called on that gutsy determination to tackle her weight problem once and for all. She said: “I’ve always had a big appetite, so I’m not sure whether it was comfort eating or just the fact I didn’t care much about my weight after Noah’s dad left. Whatever the reason, confronted with photos of herself at her  Christmas celebrations, she was shocked into slimming with gusto. Confiding in Lucy, a clothes and shoe shop assistant manager, she said: “We’ve been best friends since we were  and although we were chalk and cheese physically, we really love each other, so I knew she would support me. Too shy to go in person to a slimming club, instead she joined WW online and was soon off to a roaring start.  And Lucy was there boogying alongside her when she started following hour long YouTube dance exercise videos. Amy said: “We both love dancing and when we go out, that’s what we do … we dance, so it was the perfect exercise plan for me to start with.” Each week Amy, who now restricts her calorie intake to , a day, weighs herself on a Sunday, which is also her ‘treat’ day. Preferring savoury to sweet things, she will still forgo all snacksher weight has gone up, so she can get back on track. She said: “I know people are surprised by my determination, because they’ve seen there’s nothing I won’t say no toit means keeping my weight healthy. “As a result, I’ve only gained weight about five times since losing it and I’ve always managed to lose it again. “A pizza is my all-time favourite food, but I will say noI need to. Another thing that happens when you lose this much weight is your digestion changes, so you then have to be careful about what you eat. Luckily, exercising alongside her weight loss has also helped Amy to reduce the apron effect experienced by many people, who have had drastic weight loss and end up with large folds of loose skin. She believes using a weighted hula hoop was key to toning up as the pounds fell away. At first, she ended up with bruises to her hips and thighs when she used it but is now an expert and can keep the hoop circling around her waist for an hour at a time. She said: “I’ve lost .ins from my hips and . ins from my waist - which now measure .in and .in - thanks to working out with the hoop. “When I started this, I couldn’t even run for a bus. Now, I run three times a week on my treadmill at home which is the equivalent of - miles each week. And Iaposm hoping to do a k run for charity.” Not only has her weight loss made her feel physically better, Amy says that psychologically, she feels far more positive. “I can go into any clothes shop and wear anything I want now and when I look in the mirror, I like what I see, she said. “I’ve learned to love myself and although it sometimes still doesn’t feel real, I know that I’ve achieved this. “People tell me I am an inspiration and that makes me so happy I want to cry. But even better, I can now race Noah across the field and run around with him in the park.”Amy’s main advice to her , WW Community followers and people who follow her on Instagram - @ww__ - is to never give up on their own weight loss goals.She said: “If you have a bad day or a bad week or a bad month, just move on and start again. “I’ve had a motto for some time now which is, ‘I can and will. Watch me.apos This, basically, says to anyone that ever doubted what I was capable of, that actually it is and was possible. As for Amyaposs son, Noah, he just has one question for his mum. She said: He asks me, aposWhere’s your tummy gone apos”To learn more about WWaposs PersonalPoints programme visit ww ukAmyaposs Before Diet Breakfast - nothing Lunch - Sausage roll, crisps, chocolate, fizzy drink Dinner- Chicken Kiev and chips Snacks - chocolate and Cadbury yoghurts Amyaposs Diet Now Breakfast - overnight oats, Greek yoghurt and fruit Lunch - sweet chilli chicken and couscous, with fruit salad pudding Dinner - Salmon fillet with vegetables Snacks - fruit, rice cakes, protein yoghurtDo you have a weight loss story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BullyingFitnessWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: asda shopper utterly shocked employees
story: Asda shopper utterly shocked by employees .am random act of kindness at checkoutAsda employee Ron has been praised for his compassionate response after a shopper was unable to pay, and hes now been nominated for an Asda service superstar awardRon was praised as a wonderful asset to Asda for his kind deedByZahna EklundAudience writerRachel Pugh:,  Jan | comments A kind-hearted Asda employee has melted hearts online after he showed true compassion to a woman who couldnapost pay for her shopping.The man, referred to only as Ron, came to the rescue of the customer at the Trafford Park, Manchester, shop after she realised she had left her card at home.He generously offered to pay for the womanaposs shopping out of his own pocket - and has now been nominated for an Asda Service Superstar Award after the shopper wrote to the store to thank Ron for his kind deed, reports the Manchester Evening News. His kind actions were brought to peopleaposs attention on Asdaaposs Facebook page, with a post that read: Everyone at our Trafford Park store is so proud of their colleague Ron who paid for a regular customeraposs shopping out of his own pocket after sheaposd accidentally left her bank card at home. Ron, whoaposs worked at the store for  years, has been nominated for an Asda service superstar award after the lady wrote to our store to thank Ron, saying that her aposfaith in human beings had been restoredapos. The heart-warming details were further explained by the supermarketaposs customer trading manager, Ana, who said the shopper had rushed in just after  am on her way to work before realising sheaposd left her card at home. And rather than telling the woman sheaposd have to leave without her shopping, Ron stepped up to pay the £ himself - leaving the shopper utterly shocked by his kindness. The Facebook post continued: Ana, our storeaposs customer trading manager, said: aposThe lady was hurrying to work and when she got to our store at . am she realised while on the self-scan that sheaposd left her bank card at home. The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook She told Ron what sheaposd done and askedhe could he put the shopping away until later that afternoon, saying she would go home after work and come back – about a -minute round trip. Ron knew the customer was a regular and told her not to worry about it and paid the £ for her shopping himself. He was very happy to help out and said the customer couldat her convenience to pay him back, which she did later that day. The customer was utterly shocked by Ronaposs kind act. Commenters on the post were quick to heap praise on Ron, with many saying they will thank him personally when they next visit the Trafford Park store. One woman said: Ron is such a wonderful asset to Asda Trafford Park. He is always so pleasant and helpful and it’s always lovely to see him. It doesn’t surprise me at all that he would have done this, he really is the perfect gentleman. Well done Asda for recognising this brilliant member of staff, and well done Ron - this is well deserved. While another added: I am a regular customer at this store at Trafford and recognise Ron. This man is amazing and deserves a special award in recognition of his service, not only to customers but also to Asda. Next time I am in the store I will seek out Ron and thank him personally. And a third customer posted: Well done Ron. A lovely thing to have done. How refreshing to hear of compassion and generosity. Asda, Iaposm glad youaposre recognising a sweet work colleague.Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: blind dog who cant stop
story: Blind dog who cant stop shaking finally finds forever home with loving familyA partially blind dog with a tremor finally found her happy ending thanks to the Manchester sanctuary that gave her a chance of real happinessBlind dog who cant stop shaking finds forever family at last Image: Dogs  RescueByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Jan | commentsA partially blind dog who canapost stop shaking has finally found a forever family to spend the rest of her le with. The Romanian rescue dog had a devastating virus named distemper, which she fought with all her might to survive but left her with a permanent tremor. An angel lady in Romania nursed her back to health and taught her how to trust, before transporting her to a Manchester dog sanctuary. The Dogs  Rescue team took Damaris into their care in October, and after just three days, she was scooped up for adoption where she fitted in right away with her new family. On Monday, Dogs  Rescue shared the amazing news on theirFacebook pagein a touching post that read: “We know you’ll all be thrilled with this happy ending. Damaris has been adopted into a forever home.“We chose to rescue Damaris as she was a dog no-one  wanted. “She had suffered distemper as a pup, a highly contagious devastating viral disease which she fought with all her might to survive. “It left her blind in one eye and with a permanent tremor which made her a little dferent. “But we thought she was perfect and wanted to give this fighter a chance of real happiness. “She arrived from Romania on the happy bus in October. She was such a gentle girl. “We thought she may be with us a while in order to build her trust, but she was one of the ones that surprised us, and went on to foster within a few days and settled in brilliantly. “At the end of October, she went to live with Louise, her family and new fur brother Jerry, for her trial which we’re so pleased to announce has now become her forever home.”  Damaris’ new adopted owner Louise said: “Thank you so much for letting us home Damaris. It’s safe to say we all fell in love with her straight away. “She’s hilarious and fiesty and doesn’t let anything hold her back - she’s definitely the boss of the house! “She’s fitted in right away. If she’s not sleeping she’s playing with Jerry or telling him off when he snores. “When I saw her photo my heart melted and I knew I would do anything I could to give her a good le. “Her missing eye and tremors make her even more special to us. “Thank you to Emma for trusting us with her and also her rescuer who originally saved her for making this possible.” The Facebook post received more than , likes and  comments.One supporter wrote: “This brought a tear to my eye. She wouldnapost have stood a chance in a kennel rescue. Big thank you to her new family for giving her a chance.” Another said: “I’m crying with happiness for Damaris and her family… DR is awesome.” A third commented: “Another post from you that brought me to tears ....of happiness..... for one of your beauties finding their family. You are just fantastic and I wish happiness to Damaris and her new family.”Dogs like Damaris can be dficult to rehome and often get left behind. Dogs  Rescue’sGolden Paw Clubensures their incredible work can continue to happen.For just £ a month, you can sign up to receive exclusive behind-the-scenes stories and help save as many dogs’ lives as possible. news uk-news boy--stunned-after-filming-"Manchester: Ten-year-old captures meteor soaring overheadByAdam Dutton:,  Jan | comments A -year-old boy was stunned when he managed to film a flaming meteor as it soared over his house in Manchester.Jake Southward was warming up to go for a run with dad Anthony, , when he spotted a huge fireball in the sky.The quick-thinking schoolboy grabbed his parentsapos iPad and filmed the object as it flashed overhead at .pm last Wednesday.Jake, from Ashton on Mersey, near Sale, said he had never seen anything like it before. At first I thought it was a plane about to crash, but I realisedit was a plane about to crash it wouldaposve been going down,” he said.The youngster, who attends Wellfield Junior School, posted the video online which has since attracted hundreds of views.  Mum Yvonne, , said: The children come out with rubbish all the time”. “So you donapost really pay a lot of attention to it. But then I saw the video and I thought: aposActually, thataposs weirdapos. I said: aposYouaposd better start looking out for a bit of rock, it might be worth some moneyapos. I was going to send them down to Ashton Park to see where it landed.Late last year the Mirror reported on a meteor that was captured by a Darlington local’s doorbell camera as it shot through the sky one evening.The doorbell camera was filming after a family cat activated the recordingjust in the nick of time.  Julie Richardson, from Darlington, in the north east, said she “didn’t quite believe it” when her husband, Lee, showed her what their new doorbell camera had captured. Julie’s family cat, Stanley, is filmed between two vehicles at the bottom of the footage and happened to be walking past at just the right time to set the camera rolling. After walking theof the car, Stanley sits down on the drive, where he stays put until the impressive display is over. He then turned around and scarpers back towards the house. The fireball was spotted in Peterlee and the Northumberland coast, with residents also commenting that they saw the meteor after Julie shared the footage on social media. Julie said: I didnapost quite believe it, my husband Lee was the one that spotted it. I just thought it was a firework but that didnapost make sense as the aposfireworkapos was going down not up.”She said she put it on Facebook “just to see what other people thought about it” and came to the conclusion that it was “definitely a meteor”.The UK Meteor Network also shared several images of a meteor spotted that same evening. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

title: d day hero who carried
story: D-Day hero who carried wounded soldier over shoulder for  miles under fire dies at Denis Bounsall survived three dferent assault landings in eleven months, including D-Day, and won a Distinguished Conduct Medal for bravery. He passed away in Auckland, New Zealand, at the age of Denis Bounsall with his stained glass  that he donated to The Keep Military Museum in Dorchester in  Image: DorsetEcho BNPSByLouie SmithNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A hero who saved countless lives as a Second World War stretcher bearer, even carrying one wounded soldier for two miles over his shoulder to reach safety, has died at .Denis Bounsall enlisted at just , underage, but determined to serve his country, which he did with extraordinary bravery, once taking two prisoners armed with just a pair of scissors. He saw action in Malta, Normandy, Holland, Italy and Germany, and survived three dferent assault landings, including D-Day, in just  months.He won a Distinguished Conduct Medal for collecting casualties in a battle in Agira, Sicily, under fire with “absolute disregard of his personal safety”.  Denis joined the st Battalion the Dorsetshire Regiment in . He was a stretcher bearer during the two-year Siege of Malta, between  and , when it became “the most bombed place on earth” thanks to frequent Luftwaffe raids. Denis then ed to England to train for the Allied invasion of Europe.  He landed at Gold Beach at am on D-Day and later spoke about his experiences. Denis said: “We were under constant fire and my job was just to pick people up as they fell. I would listen for the screams around me and do what I could to assist.” One of just , soldiers awarded a DCM, after the war he became a stained glass window artist and emigrated to Auckland, New Zealand, where he died. French historian Gerard Pouchain met Denis in , when he ed to the Normandy town of Asnelles, where he had landed on June , , and presented the community with a glass  bearing his regimental crest. Mr Pouchain said: “He will forever remain at the heart of the community where he landed in .” A spokesman for The Keep Military Museum in Dorchester said: “We will remember Denis as a brave soldier, keen artist and friend.” Richard Palusinski, chairman of the Spirit of Normandy Trust, said: “We owe Denis and all his comrades a tremendous debt of thanks.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Normandy CampaignSiege of MaltaSoldiersEnergy billsMuseumsDaily Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news eerie-footage-shows-inside-spooky-"Eerie footage reveals inside of abandoned polo clubByJasmine KazlauskasRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments This eerie footage has captured the untouched inside of a creepy polo club that has been abandoned since .The intriguing clip was filmed by urban explorer Dax Ward after being informed about the mysterious location by another photographer friend.The -year-old, from Arkansas, USA, visited the Garden City Polo Club in Bangkok, Thailand, last month and shared these ominous images and video from his time exploring the formerly prestigious club.The computer scientist said: “I’m continually looking for unusual abandoned places to document. “I’ve explored a few other athletic event facilities, including a baseballs stadium in the US, but this was the first polo club I’ve ever been to, either defunct or active.  “It opened in  and only operated for a few years into the mid-late aposs. I was told by the caretaker that it closed in . “A lot of capital was put into this site as it is enormous, with an opulent architectural design rarely seen in Thailand. The original site had over a dozen buildings aside from the main grounds, which included stables and both an indoor arena and outdoor playing field.  “The clock fountain, furniture, ornate staircases and decaying piano were the highlights for me, with the clock fountain being the most interesting  Dali-esque feature. “They really bring out an undeniable surrealist aesthetic.”  Dax added that he could understand why ghost hunters may pick up some activity in the abandoned location, as there were some definite ‘spooky’ spots. He said: “I have a Thai ghost-hunter friend who has spent time at the polo club with his paranormal team. “I’m not surethey found anything but wouldn’t be surprisedthey did, as the place, although beautul, has some spooky spots.  “Walking around the facility, it isnapost hard to imagine horses and riders scurrying around during and between matches, people having drinks at the bar and spectators watching the action on the fields. “The few short years that it was in operation must have been a sight to behold. “Nowadays, as is obvious from the pictures, everything is decaying and being overtaken by flora and fauna.  The aposfaunaapos being a pack of aggressive soi dogs, snakes and lizards, as well as the fish in a nearby canal, which seems to be a popular local spot to cast a line. “I really enjoyed visiting this location and would put it easily in the top  of my favourite abandoned sites in Thailand.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Abandoned placesThailand" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news every-covid-rule-being-lted-"UK records  new coronavirus daily deathsByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Boris Johnson has confirmed that all Covid Plan B measures will come to an end in England this week on Thursday January . This means that mandatory mask-wearing on public transport and in shops, work-from-home guidance and the need for Covid passes will all be axed, despite rates of Omicron infection still surging across the country. UK will revert to Plan A with a focus on vaccine rollout, with Health Secretary Sajid Javid warning last Wednesday that itaposs not the end of the road eventhe number of cases are falling.This means that the end of Plan B does not mean the end of restrictions altogether. Here are the rules being removed tomorrow and what will remain. What restrictions will be removed when Plan B ends As of Thursday, January , Covid passes for large venues will end. However, Boris Johnson said that venues would have the right to choose on whether or not they want to continue with the policy.Work-from-home guidance ended last week, with people ing to offices almost immediately after it was axed. Similarly, face coverings are no longer a legal requirement in public spaces including transport and shops. Face masks will also no longer be required in classrooms. Though the government no longer mandates wearing masks in any setting, Johnson added urged that people should still think about wearing a mask when in public environments, particularly in crowded or enclosed spaces. Restrictions on visiting care homes will also be eased. But Mr Javid warned that the end of Plan B shouldnapost be seen as the finish line. He urged people to continue taking protective measures including washing hands, ventilating rooms and self-isolatingpositive. Anyone who has yet to receive their Covid vaccines are also being urged to come forward. Which Covid rules will remain   Along with self-isolating for at least five full daysyou get a positive Covid test, the requirement to take lateral flow tests when travelling internationally will remain in place. While legal requirements stay in place for now, Johnson said he hoped to not have to renew self-isolation rules when they expire on March . He added that the aim is to remove the legal requirement for people to isolate after testing positive and replace it with advice and guidance as the virus becomes endemic.  For now, anyone planning to travel abroad need to book and pay for a Covid test before coming back to England - although this will change on February  from amyouaposre double-vaccinated. From now until then the test - either lateral flow or PCR - will have to be taken after you arrive back. If the test comes back positive, you need to self-isolate. Those who arenapost fully vaccinated need to book and pay for day two and day eight tests. You will also have to quarantine at home or the place youaposre staying for  full days. If youaposve been fully vaccinated then you donapost need to isolate for  days unless you test positive on or before day two.Everyone also needs to complete apassenger locator formbefore travelling back to the UK.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CoronavirusPlan BOmicron iantBoris Johnson" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: everything know far more contagious
story: Everything we know so far about more contagious new ‘stealth Omicron’ Covid strainEarly data suggests the BA. iant could be . times more infectious than the original Omicron strain, but initial studies have not shown a dference in the risk of hospitalisationUK health officials are officially monitoring a new Covid- strain, nicknamed “stealth Omicron Image: Getty ImagesByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments UK health officials are officially monitoring a new Covid- strain, nicknamed “stealth Omicron ”, that appears to be more contagious than the original Omicron strain. Early data suggests that BA., a sub-iant believed to have emerged from a mutation of the Omicron coronavirus iant, may be both more transmissible and better able to evade vaccines than the more common BA. sub-lineage.Currently the BA. lineage accounts for % of all cases globally but in Denmark, the BA. has grown rapidly.In the last week of , it accounted for % of all Covid- cases. By the second week of , it accounted for % of cases. On Wednesday, it was reported that BA. had become the dominant strain in Denmark.In a national address on Wednesday, Danish Health Minister Magnus Heunicke said: “There is no evidence that the BA. iant causes more disease, but it must be more contagious.”  Initial calculations by Denmarkaposs top infectious disease authority, Statens Serum Institut, show BA. could be . times more infectious than BA.. So far, early data has not shown a dference in the risk of hospitalisation for BA. compared to BA.. There is some indication that it is more contagious, especially for the unvaccinated, but that it can also infect people who have been vaccinated to a greater extent, SSIaposs technical director Tyra Grove Krause said at the briefing on Wednesday. The BA. has been nicknamed “stealth Omicron” as it is poses a challenge for scientists to track, unlike the original Omicron that stood out on the widely-used PCR tests without the need for extra genome sequencing. The new strain shows up as being S-gene positive under PCR tests, whereas the BA. did not.  According to the World Health Organisation, BA. sequences have been reported in more than  countries, including the UK, Sweden, Norway, Singapore and India. On Friday, the UK Health Security Agency designated BA. a “iant under investigation” – one level below a “iant of concern” – saying it could have a growth advantage. It is the nature of viruses to evolve and mutate, so itaposs to be expected that we will continue to see new iants emerge, Dr Meera Chand, incident director at the UKHSA, said. Our continued genomic surveillance allows us to detect them and assess whether they are signicant.  So far, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether BA. causes more severe illness than omicron BA., but data is limited and UKHSA continues to investigate.” In the UK, some  cases of the BA. sub-lineage have been sequenced, according to Reuters, and the UKHSA said early analysis suggested an increased growth rate compared to BA.. Imperial College London’s Tom Peacock, one of the first virologists to raise the alarm over Omicron, tweeted that very early observations from India and Denmark suggest there is no dramatic dference in severity compared to BA.. This data should become more solidin the coming weeks.” He added that there is likely to be minimal dferences in vaccine effectiveness against BA. and BA.. Personally, Iaposm not sure BA. is going to have a substantial impact on the current Omicron wave of the pandemic. Several countries are near, or even past the peak of BA. waves. I would be very surprisedBA. caused a second wave at this point. Even with slightly higher transmissibility this absolutely is not a Delta-Omicron change and instead is likely to be slower and more subtle, he continued. news uk-news five-times-prince-andrew-appeared-"Prince Andrews car-crash Newsnight interviewByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan  In his car crash interview on BBC Newsnight over two years ago, Prince Andrew made the famous claim that he had an inability to sweat.He used the condition to deny claims from Virginia Giuffre, who alleges they had sex in  when she was  years old. Andrew vehemently denies the allegations. In the interview, where Andrew was quizzed over his association with his billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, the Duke of York said he didnapost remember meeting Giuffre. However, she claims that on the night of one of their alleged encounters, Andrew sweated heavily as they danced at Tramp nightclub in London.  The Prince told Newsnight: There’s a slight problem with the sweating because I have a peculiar medical condition which is that I don’t sweat or I didn’t sweat at the time and that was…was it…yes, I didn’t sweat at the time because I had suffered what I would describe as an overdose of adrenalin in the Falkland’s War when I was shot at and I simply…it was almost impossible for me to sweat. However, there have been accounts and pictures of the Duke, where he appears to seem sweaty - despite his claims in the interview... Nightclub, Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. In July , a then -year-old Andrew was spotted leaving Londonaposs Chinawhite nightclub - a favourite nightspot of celebrities in the Soho area. Pictures from the night show the Duke of York in a blue, unbuttoned shirt, appearing to look slightly sweaty. London, In a interview with the BBCaposs Panorama in , Virginia Giuffre alleged Andrew was sweaty during an encounter she says took place at Tramp nightclub in London in . In the interview, she alleged how she was brought to London by Epstein in , introduced to Andrew and taken to Tramp nightclub, and asked by the duke to dance. She told Panorama reporter Darragh Macintyre: He is the most hideous dancer Iaposve ever seen in my le. It was horrible and this guy was sweating all over me, his sweat was like it was raining basically everywhere, I was just like grossed out from it, but I knew I had to keep him happy because thataposs what Jeffrey and Ghislaine would have expected from me. Saint Tropez,  Pictures from  show Andrew at a party in Saint Tropez with a shiny face ashe had been sweating , although the cause is not clear, as he received a hug from American socialite Chris Von Aspen as she attempts to lick him.In other pictures taken from the same night, Andrew rests his arms around Von Aspenaposs waist and then neck as she dances in her white mini dress. Billionaire party,  Meanwhile, another set of snaps shows the Prince appearing to look apossweaty and wild-eyedapos dancing with Canadian socialite Pascale Borubeau at a bash thrown by billionaire Tony Murray in Saint Tropez in the same year, according to the Sun A former Saint-Tropez party-goer told the MailOnline: aposThese were really crazy years for Andrew. He was clearly having a full-blown midle crisis. He would have been  or  at the time, orced from Sarah Ferguson, and basking in the attention he got from young women. Golf at Buckingham Palace  In , former royal protection officer from  to  Paul Page told the Mirror he saw the Prince perspiring while playing golf in the garden at Buckingham Palace.Mr Page, who was convicted in  over a £million investment fraud, insisted he did not have a grudge against the duke but added the prince was “abusive and rude towards us as police officers”. The Palace said previously during Mr Page’s trial he made “a series of allegations about... members of the Royal Family, none of which were ever substantiated”. title: former radio 1 xtra dj
story: Ex-Radio  Xtra DJ fined for lockdown rave days before Downing Street partyDJ Maressa Innerarity was fined £, for her involvement in an illegal rave held in November , days before a party was hosted at the Downing Street flatFormer BBC Radio  Xtra DJ Maressa Innerarity was fined £, for her involvement in the warehouse rave Image: TwitterByAdela WhittinghamCourt ReporterAntony Thrower:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A supremely selfish former BBC Radio  Xtra DJ has been fined for her involvement in a rave with  people, held days after a lockdown was announced.Police were called by a resident complaining about the noise at a warehouse in Bethnal Green in November  when the country was socially distancing. City of London Magistrates’ Court heard self-styled “international DJ” Maressa Innerarity, who also goes by the name Carmen London, was not the event’s organiser but arrived with her own sound system. Prosecutor Nathan Paine-Davey said this is enough to charge her with holding or being involved in holding a rave type gathering in England of more than  people indoors. Innerarity admitted the offence on the first day of a trial.The party was held three days before an alleged Downing Street flat party on the same day as Boris Johnson ’s chief adviser, Dominic Cummings, and communications director, Lee Cain, left their roles.The prosecutor said: “This relates to November  and . The defendant has been charged with an offence against the public protection coronavirus restrictions regulations which were in force on November , .“On November , the police were called to Poyser Street as a result of a complaint of noise from a resident in the block of flats. They believed that there was some sort of event going on. When police arrived they met with local officers and they could hear loud music coming from the location and approximately  to  people in the street leading up to the location. A cordon was placed on the street. At that point, police entered the building and stopped the unlicensed music event. It is believed  to  people were in the premises. Itaposs described as a squat - itaposs a warehouse-type building with very low ceilings. The court was shown police body-worn footage of attendees “pouring out” of the venue after officers shut down the event.  Mr Davey-Paine said: She accepted at the scene the music equipment was indeed hers and she was then warned she may well be prosecuted under the regulations. Clearly it was unlikely that that number of people would gather in such a space simply to have a chat. I donapost say the defendant organised it but the presence of her musical equipment and obviously she has been employed as a disc jockey previously. There is no evidence she was in fact operating that equipment. Eric Kawoya, defending, said Innerarity had been asked by two friends named aposGabriel and Jamalaposthey could borrow her sound equipment. He told the court his client did not know the equipment would be used for a party. Mr Kawoya said: She packed them in the car and drove to the venue. She was not told what kind ofwas taking place. When she arrived at the venue at the time the place was empty but as time went by, people started to arrive. She had cause for concern and she asked what was going on and they said to her not to worry. She then stayed around. She was not given any sort of money for this. She couldnapost leave because she was concerned for the safety of the speakers and damage to the speakers.The court heard Innerarity has not worked in two years and is on Universal Credit.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  District Judge Tim Godfrey said: It was a loud gathering to all intents and purposes, a rave was held there. It was sufficiently disturbing to neighbours that police were called. Most signicant of course this was during the national lockdown that began on November . That is a fact of which you were aware as of course was everyone at the event. It is clear from the video footage that people were crowded into a cramped location. It was a blatant breach of the lockdown and coronavirus regulations in force at the time. You said you didnapost appreciate what they would be used for but it was inconceivable that you did not appreciate the gathering was used for some kind of unlawful gathering during the lockdown.It is hard to imagine an event more likely to spread Covid- than the sort of event being held on this occasion.What those attending may have been willing to risk is not only their own health and wellbeing, they risked the health and wellbeing of others who they may be in contact with subsequently and they may be more vulnerable. Those who attended this event were acting in a supremely selfish way. Innerarity, of Tooting, south London, was fined £, and ordered to pay £ prosecution costs and a £ surcharge. title: healthy fit british dad 68
story: Healthy and fit British dad, , drowns in hotel yoga tragedy after moving to IndiaIain Francis, , had recently retired to India and was enjoying his daily ritual of yoga practice at the riverside by his hotel when he accidentally fell into the water and drownedIain Francis had recently retired to IndiaByAnita Merritt:,  Jan | commentsA aposhealthy and fitapos father died in a yoga tragedy at a hotel after moving to India. Iain Francis, , had recently retired to India and was enjoying his daily ritual of yoga practice at the riverside by his hotel when he accidentally fell into the water and drowned. The dad-of-three, from Moretonhampstead, is believed to have hit his head during the fall on March , , and is likely to have been unconscious by the time he went into the water.An inquest at Exeter’s County Hall on January , heard the family had endured a long wait for more information surrounding his death from the Foreign Commonwealth Office and Indian police authorities due to the coronavirus pandemic, reports Devon Live. The -year-old, who had no known medical conditions, was described by his daughter Angela as having been aposextremelyapos healthy and fit for his age and did yoga every day to help ease pain in his hips, knees and sometimes also his feet.  In a statement, she recalled: He went to India in October  to enjoy this retirement warmer climate where he could stretch and climatise. He intended indeed to come back in the spring. Mr Francis had previously been a plumber for many years but also had an extensive career working in microfinance as a financial consultant in foreign agricultural programmes. He worked in  countries including Nigeria, Vietnam and Bangladesh. After retiring he travelled to India on his own and had been staying in the district of Koppal in Karnataka. The location of his death was Hanumanahalli Thungabhandra River Gangavathi. His daughter recalled the majority of his trip had been spent near the sea in Goa. Angela said: He was a strong swimmer, although he did not attempt to go in the water much or for long periods in later years.  The manager of the hotel where Mr Francis was staying told police in India that every day he would do yoga and body exercises at a riverbank near the hotel. On the day of his death he left the hotel at .pm and at pm the hotel manager was informed he had fallen in the river. He recalled he had gone to the river and saw Mr Francis floating in the water wearing shorts, and his belongings were on the bank of the river. The police investigation confirmed Mr Francis had accidentally fallen down into the river and had hit his head on a rock on his way into the water. The conclusion was he had died by accidental drowning and there was no third party involvement. A post mortem examination conducted in India confirmed the cause of Mr Francisaposs death was drowning. It was noted that there were lacerations to his scalp and a deep injury on the left side of the top of his head. Recording a narrative conclusion, coroner Philip Spinney said: “The deceased died from the effects of drowning.” Following the inquest, his daughters paid tribute to Mr Francis and said: Our dad was wonderfully caring, funny, sensitive and generous. He had a spirit, heart and presence like no one  and he will always be dearly missed. title: highway code changes cyclists important
story: Highway Code changes for cyclists - important new rules for those on bikesCycling on the roads can dangerous. We take a look at the latest new changes to the Highway Code being brought in for Rush hour can be a hectic time for people on two wheelsByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Jan | comments The Highway Code is set to have some crucial updates made to it this week. The changes are set to impact all kinds of road users but will have the overall goal of making roads safer for people on foot, bikes and horses.The changes are coming into play after a huge consultation with the public was conducted to find out what people wanted and how they used the roads. , people took part in the consultation, with the government saying that most people who responded were in favour of the proposed changes.The new rules will work to make motorists more aware of cyclists and pedestrians, ensuring a safer experience for all road users.When are the Highway Code changes coming in January   The changes will be made from Saturday, January , with eight changes in total set to come into force. We take a look at all the ones likely to affect cyclists Road user hierarchy Three new changes are coming in that will impact road use hierarchy. This rule enforces the idea that motorists need to be more aware of cyclists, and cyclists need to be more aware of pedestrians.The change in rules will see users who are most at risk moved to the top of the hierarchy.The government website says: The hierarchy places those road users most at risk in the event of a collision at the top of the hierarchy. It does not remove the need for everyone to behave responsibly. People crossing at junctions  According to the government, the new update will mean that:When people are crossing or waiting to cross at a junction, other traffic should give waypeople have started crossing and traffic wants to turn into the road, the people crossing have priority and the traffic should give way people driving, riding a motorcycle or cycling must give way to people on a zebra crossing and people walking and cycling on a parallel crossingA parallel crossing is similar to a zebra crossing, but includes a cycle route alongside the black and white stripes. Walking cycling and riding in shared spaces  Shared areas will ask that people on pushbikes respect the safety of people walking, although pedestrians too must take care not to endanger anyone. The government says: People cycling are asked to:not pass people walking, riding a horse or driving a horse-drawn vehicle closely or at high speed, particularly from behind slow down when necessary and let people walking know they are thereremember that people walking may be deaf, blind or partially sighted avoid passing a horse on the horse’s leftPositioning in the road when cycling  The road position that cyclists take up when using highways is due to have updated guidance. The government will now ask cyclists to begin:riding in the centre of their lane on quiet roads, in slower-moving traffic and at the approach to junctions or road narrowings keeping at least . metresaway from the kerb edgewhen riding on busy roads with vehicles moving faster than themThis section of the code will also impact people riding in groups, saying they:should be considerate of the needs of other road users when riding in groups can ride  abreast - and it can be safer to do so, particularly in larger groups or when accompanying children or less experienced riders Cyclists are also asked to be aware of people driving behind them and let them overtakethey wish to. This might include moving into a single file or even stoppingnecessary.It also discusses that people riding bikes need to:take care when passing parked vehicles, leaving enough roomto avoid being hita car door is opened watch out for people walking into their pathOvertaking when cycling  Updates are expected about safe passing distances, as well as speeds. The government say this will include:leaving at least . metreswhen overtaking people cycling at speeds of up to mph, and giving them more space when overtaking at higher speeds passing people riding horses or driving horse-drawn vehicles at speeds under  mph and allowing at least  metresof space allowing at least  metresof space and keeping to a low speed when passing people walking in the road This also means waiting behind someone and not overtaking until it is safe to do so by meeting these spaces. The update will also confirm that people cycling may pass slower-moving or stationary traffic on their right or left, although they are advised to be careful as people they pass might not be able to see them. People cycling at junctions  When turning in or out of a side road you need to give way to people waiting to cross or who are already walking across. The government also say: Some junctions now include small cycle traffic lights at eye-level height, which may allow cyclists to move separately from or before other traffic. People cycling are encouraged to use these facilities where they make their journey safer and easier. If there are no separate cycling facilities on a junction, then people on bikes should behave in the same way as car drivers. This will mean, where safe, positioning yourself in the middle of your correct lane at junctions. When it comes to turning right, advice is be handed down for cyclists using junctions that involve making the turn in two stages:stage  - when the traffic lights turn green, go straight ahead to the location marked by a cycle symbol and turn arrow on the road, and then stop and wait stage  - when the traffic lights on the far side of the junctionturn green, complete the manoeuvre The new advice also adds that people on bikes have priority when going straight ahead on junctions.They have priority over traffic waiting to turn into or out of a side road, unless road signs or markings indicate otherwise, the government says. People cycling are asked to watch out for people driving intending to turn across their path, as people driving ahead may not be able to see them. Cycling on a roundabout  Drivers and motorcyclists should now give priority to cyclists on roundabouts. The guidance will say they should:not attempt to overtake people cycling within that person’s lane allow people cycling to move across their path as they travel around the roundaboutCyclists will still be able to remain in the left-hand lane when going across or around a roundabout. The new guidance is due that will tell motorists to pay extra attention to this, taking care not to cut off cyclists doing this. title: huge drive thru kebab shop
story: Huge drive-thru kebab shop seeks to open in UK first which will rival likes of KFCThe new fast food joint would serve hungry drivers and diners at its two-storey restaurant which is planned to take prime position in Bolton, Greater ManchesterA recently submitted plan seeks to convert an empty building into a two-storey kebab restaurantByChris GeeLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA huge drive-thru kebab restaurant is on the cards for Greater Manchester which could rival the likes of McDonaldaposs and KFC. Plans have been submitted for a two-storey restaurant in Bolton town centre to serve the classic late night feast to both indoor diners and passing drivers. Documents suggest converting an empty premises into the drive-thru restaurant under the German Doner Kebab name. It would transform the currently shabby and deserted building into an urban chic kebab joint equipped for all.Glossy CGI images published by Bolton Council in support of the application show its intended transformation, reports Manchester Evening News.The site was previously used by charities including the Mental Health Independent Support Team and Bolton NICE, which develops community and business enterprises and job opportunities.  Synergie Holdings submitted the proposal and opening hours for the venture are unknown at this stage. Five on-site parking spots would be created at the site, according to the application. Responding to the form, Boltonaposs highways department said it will need more information before giving an opinion. It said: “Owing to the premises location in relation to the highways around the town centre of Bolton, the applicant will need to submit some form of transport statement in order to justy the proposed change of use.  “The statement should provide a rough indication as to how accessibility to the premises will be controlled and how abuse of the one-way system on Gas Street will be prevented, as well as giving a rough indication of traffic impact from the proposed use. “In its present form there is insufficient information available within the submission for the Highway Authority to fully comment.” The drive-thru kebab restaurant will be considered by planners in Bolton after a period of consultation with neighbours. title: im worlds most prolific sperm
story: Im worlds most prolic sperm donor with  kids - I give it away free on FacebookRetired teacher -year-old Clive Jones was unable to become an official sperm donor but now gives it away for free to people on Facebook and wants to get to  babies before giving upClive Jones offers his sperm to people for free Image: Clive JonesByKelly-Ann MillsNews ReporterBen Lyons:,  Jan | commentsA man who has been donating his sperm for the last nine years claims to be the worldaposs most prolic donor and says he has fathered  children and has nine more on the way.Retired teacher Clive Jones donates his sperm using the unregulated world of Facebook, where he claims he found an overwhelming demand.Having only started donating his sperm aged , but was unable to become an official sperm donor because banks have an upper donor age limit of . Health experts have issued a medical warning regarding his activities, saying that all donors and patients should be treated at a licensed UK clinic.Mr Jones, , himself told Derbyshire Live heaposs had a lot of people question him over why he does it, but believes they would understandthey saw the happiness it brings to the families he provides his free donations to. He said: Iaposm probably the worldaposs most prolic sperm donor with now being at  aposbabiesapos, well,  babies born, nine ongoing pregnancies. I might continue for another few years. Get to  anyway. I know of clinics and sperm merchants with greater numbers but they donapost donate, but rather sell semen. I think people would understand morethey saw the messages I get and the photos of the babies with very happy mothers. I feel the happiness it brings. I once had a grandmother message me thanking me for her granddaughter. I do it for free, though sometimes ask a bit for petrol. Itaposs illegal to charge and doesnapost seem right to take money when I have more than them. Mr Jones, who has three grown-up children of his own, said: It all started in May, over nine years ago. For some people, having children is very important as it was for me. I read in some newspapers the plight of some people that canapost have children. Reading the newspaper, it explained how people were using Facebook to make arrangements. I thought I could help so I put a post on one of the sites. I wasnapost expecting any response with me saying how old I was, but I had a lady in Derby contacting me within an hour asking me to help that evening.  Iaposve not advertised Iaposm a donor in years. It has not quite worked out as I had guessed, Iaposm just as busy now and have so many people contact me through people just talking, referring. The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority has issued a medical warning regarding Mr Jonesapos activities, saying that all donors and patients should be treated at a licensed UK clinic. A spokeswoman for the authority said: As the regulator of UK fertility treatment and research we donapost have the powers to stop people from making their own arrangements for sperm donation but we do want to help them get the information and advice they need to make the best informed choices, which is why we always encourage both donors and patients to be treated at a licensed UK clinic. If arrangements are made outside of the clinic environment there can be medical and legal risks, for example, without the proper consents in place the donor is likely to be seen as the legal parent, with all the rights and responsibilities that involves. Clinics will also rigorously test all donors for medical and hereditary illnesses. That’s why we always encourage sperm donors and patients to go to a licensed clinic, where these medical and legal issues are taken care of for them, and where the welfare of the child is always of primary concern.  Mr Jones says heaposs been married since , but now lives apart from his we who he says is not at all happy about what he does.Back in , Mr Jones appeared in  Men  Babies, a Channel  documentary which follows the lives of four men who donate their sperm for free to women who contacted them online. A clip from the show was featured on Gogglebox, which has received more than four million views on Facebook. Of the  children he claims to have fathered, Mr Jones says heaposs met around  of the babies which are located within around a -mile radius of Derby, including in Birmingham, Stoke and Nottingham. After first making contact, Mr Jones says he then gets to know the couple, who are often same-sex or cannot have children of their own, and discuss when their ovulation cycle is. He said he then places the date on his planner, and when he gets the call saying ovulation is only hours away, he jumps into his van and drives close to where they live. Describing how he does it, Mr Jones previously told Derbyshire Live : I drive somewhere where Iaposm not likely to be disturbed and go into the back of the van and pull the curtains down. Then I take the cup and a syringe so the stuff canapost come out, put a bag under my arm and text them to say Iaposm outside and Iaposll be round in three minutes. If that doesnapost work sometimes they suggest I meet them in a car park. I can tell how nervous they are. No other donor does it from their van normally, they go to the front door and ask to use the toilet. news uk-news kate-middleton-pays-solo-visit-"Kate Middleton visits Shout  to mark milestoneByRussell MyersRoyal EditorJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments The Duchess of Cambridge today paid a solo visit to a mental health service she set up with Meghan Markle almost three years ago. Shout - a text service for people struggling with their mental health - was Kate and Prince William’s first major project with Meghan and Prince Harry.It launched in May  following a £million investment from the Royal Foundation, when the royals were dubbed the Fab Four. However, today when visiting the service in Londonaposs Notting Hill, Kate was flying solo as she met volunteers and those who have raised funds for the organisation. Among them was a teenage Scout who raised £, for the service by sleeping outside in a hammock for a year. Kate met Leo Street, , and called him ‘an inspiration’ after he braved temperatures as low as minus five to raise money for the charity.The duchess, who wore a £ olive green Derek Lam dress and £ ASOS earrings, joked: “There really isn’t a big enough Scout badge for that. What you achieved is really inspiring.”“You must have had some impressive kit to keep warm,” she said.Leo, from Swanley, slept under a heavy-duty tarpaulin to shield him from the extremities of the weather. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He told the duchess his next fundraising adventure will be to cycle to Scotland during half term. Mark Ungless, , an analytics expert, said that children as young as  and under formed eight per cent of their texts – which are received mostly between pm and midnight “I told the duchess we were surprised by the number of very young people reaching out and the time too. It needs addressing,” he said. Kate’s visit to Shout was to mark the mental health text service reaching over one million text conversations with those in need and struggling to cope.Shout has seen usage on its  increase by  per cent since the start of the COVID- pandemic and Kate was hearing how it needs more volunteers to join to ensure it can meet growing demand.The duchess was also told that conversations taking place on the Shout can be used to provide insights on mental health in the UK, with suicide , depressionand anxiety or stress , being cited as the main reasons why texters have sought support. During the visit, Kate also viewed a live demonstration of the  before joining a small group of Shout Volunteers to hear about their experiences of helping those in distress. She was also shown how people have personally benefited from taking part in the service, including by gaining new skills and developing a sense of purpose and also met Cassie Waters who began raising money for Shout after using the service herself when she suffered mental health challenges in . During her visit, Kate also met clinical supervisors, volunteers, and fundraisers to thank them for their invaluable efforts to ensure that vital mental health support is available across the UK at any time of day or night. She heard how the service is inviting members of the public to become Shout Volunteers to meet the growing demand for support. news uk-news kate-middleton-wears--earrings-"Kate Middleton visits Shout  to mark milestoneByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments The Duchess of Cambridge once again proved she loves a bargain by wearing a pair of £ earrings while visiting a mental health text service she helped to establish. Kate met volunteers, clinical supervisors and fundraisers at Shout  this morning, which was launched by the Cambridges and backed by their Royal Foundation in .For the visit, Kate sported an olive green patterned dress with a pussybow neckline costing £ by Derek Lam alongside a pair of black boots from Ralph Lauren. Her simple jewellery included the £ gold-plated earrings from online fashion giant ASOS - and itaposs not the first time sheaposs worn them.They also got an outing last October when Kate gave a keynote speech to launch the Action on Addiction campaign.She also wore them while attending the re-opening of the VA Museum in London in May . Kateaposs visit to Shout today came as the organisation marked a milestone one million text conversations. Use of the  has jumped by  per cent since the start of the pandemic, and Kate was told of the need for more volunteers to meet the growing demand. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. The duchess was also shown how the service works in London, and joined a small group of volunteers to hear about their experiences helping the distressed. Shout is the UK’s only   text messaging support service and offers confidential help for anyone struggling to cope. It is free to start a conversation by texting SHOUT to  from all major mobile networks in the UK. Round-the-clock support comes from clinical supervisors and some , trained volunteers.The service was the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge’s first major project with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, with the service launched following a £ million investment from the Royal Foundation in May .The couples were dubbed the fab four, but Harry and Meghan split from the Foundation a month later to set up their own charitable organisation before quitting as senior working royals in . Itaposs been a busy few days for Kate, who also carried out two engagements last week.Last Wednesday she visited the Foundling Museum in London with her husband Prince William, where she also wore bargain £ earrings from Accessorize.The next day they were in Lancashire, where they went to Clitheroe Community Hospital and Church on the Street - a centre that helps those struggling with addiction and poverty.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Kate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: maida vale mum texted friend
story: Maida Vale: Mum had texted friend saying psychotic ex would kill her before her deathThe politan Police issued an arrest warrant for Leon McCaskre three weeks before he brutally killed Yasmin Chkai on the streets of Maida ValeYasmin Chkai , a mum-of-two, was stabbed on the streets of Maida Vale, west London on Monday morning Image: Yasmin Chkai TwitterByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A woman told a friend that her apospsychoticapos ex-husband would kill her before he stabbed her to death in the street. The politan Police had issued an arrest warrant for Leon McCaskre three weeks before he brutally killed Yasmin Chkai on the streets of Maida Vale, west London on Monday morning. As the -year-old repeatedly stabbed the mum-of-two with a kitchen kne, a -year-old motorist allegedly ploughed his car into the killer. Paramedics were unable to save either Yasmin, a qualied childminder and masters student, or McCaskre. Before her death, the mum-of-two had told friend Adele-Sara Richards that he had put cameras in her flat and had stolen her mail and phone in order to get her personal information. Ms Richard said that in April  she messaged her to say: Heaposs had cameras in my house recording me for months. She went on: Heaposs stolen my mail, my phone, has access to all my personal data. I think he will kill me. Iaposve tried everything. Family members, including two young men thought to be her  and -year-old sons, said that the -year-old had a panic alarm installed in her flat. They also accused Scotland Yard of doing nothing to help the mum, who they said took a restraining order out against McCaskre and orced him three years ago. Records show that McCaskre was wanted for failing to appear in court on January  after breaching stalking orders banning him from contacting Yasmin, The Times reports.  Deon Nelson-Wright, a close friend and former flatmate of the mum, said she knew the psychotic man spelt bad news for her pal from the moment they met. She told The Mirror: I knew this was going to happen. I just knew it. He was psychotic. A petition has been launched dubbing the unnamed driver a hero and calling for him not to face criminal charges. On Tuesday he was released on bail after being arrested on suspicion of murder. A friend told The Mirror that the driver, thought to be a dad-of-three, was in shock and living in a nightmare. The Met has referred itself to the Independent Office for Police Conduct.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON RyanairScotland Yardpolitan PoliceMurderCrimeKne crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man 32 admits kidnapping girl
story: Man, , admits kidnapping girl, , as she made her way to schoolDavid Young from Crawley, West Sussex, has pleaded guilty to kidnapping a girl, , as well admitting to breaching a sexual offence prevention orderdating back to Stock image of Hove Crown Court Image: Google mapsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan  dating back to " data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Hove-Crown-Court.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" dating back to " data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Hove-Crown-Court.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" dating back to " data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Hove-Crown-Court.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"A man has pleaded guilty to kidnapping a -year-old girl as she made her way to school. David Young, of Garton Close, Ifield, Crawley, West Sussex, also admitted breaching a sexual offence prevention orderdating back to September  for having unsupervised contact with a child. The -year-old chef denied kidnapping the teenager with intent to commit a sexual offence and a further breach of the SOPO by accessing a social networking site. Sussex Police said the girl was approached on her way to school in the Three Bridges area of Crawley by a man wearing a yellow high visibility jacket on October , . He reportedly took her to a nearby area away from the road and searched her clothing before leaving the scene on a bicycle. The girl, whose identity cannot be revealed legally, was unharmed and given support, the force said. Judge Christine Henson QC adjourned the case at Hove Crown Court until February  for the prosecution to decide whether to proceed with a trial on the remaining two charges set to be held on March .Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Sussex PoliceEducationSchoolsCourt caseCrown courtTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
