title: moray mum who shed seven stone during pandemic to scale britains three highest mountains
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. title: freeports talks back on between scottish and uk governments
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. title: andrew musgrave ready give all pursuit winter olympics medal
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: tee to green steve scott luke donald is a perfect compromise candidate for ryder cup captain
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: winter olympics freestyle skier kirsty muir proud to represent aberdeen as she prepares to make bow in beijing
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: biggar-man-called-sevens-team
story: A FORMER Biggar High School pupil has been selected to join the Scotland s squad.Reiss Cullen, , has travelled to Malaga to join Scotland’s s team on tour.On his selection, Reiss said: “It was a good feeling. It’s something I’ve wanted to do for my whole career and for it to finally become reality is exciting.”Reiss also plays for Watsonians in the Super, and previously played for Biggar.“He started in S at Biggar High School,” said his mum, Jo, “then he played with Biggar from S probably to about S and then he went to play for Watsonians.”She added: “He’s had so many knocks back, we’re absolutely chuffed for him.”Looking ahead to his time with the squad, Reiss said: “I’m looking forward to going away to dferent locations around the world with a tight group of boys and playing against the best players in the world.”Scotland have drawn in Pool A in the Malaga leg of the HSBC World Sevens Series. Reiss will play this weekend, before the team moves on to Seville.

title: victories-hawick-gala-biggar-melrose-weekend
story: IN A busy weekend of club rugby Hawick took the honours in the Premiership Borders derby, beating Jed-Forest - at the Riverside.Hawick’s tries came from Andrew Mitchell , Ruaridh McLeod and Shawn Muir. Kirk Ford scored four conversions and added two penalties. Gregor Young and Paulo Ferreira scored for Jed.That result all but secures Hawick’s place in the top-four play-offs. Jed are now in sixth place but still looking over their shoulders at the bottom of the table.Selkirk lost - in the capital to Edinburgh Accies. Their points came from two Scott Clark penalties and one from Callum Anderson. That result leaves the Souters in second bottom place which could see them needing a play off victory to retain their top-flight status.In National League One Gala secured a four-try bonus point - victory over Dundee in a hard fought encounter at Netherdale. Gala’s tries came from Taylor Wilson, Angus Dun, John Turnbull and Fergus Johnston. Craig Dods scored three conversions.Melrose ed to the Borders with five points after an emphatic - victory over Cartha Queen’s Park. Melrose tries came from Richard Ferguson, Gavin Wood , James Brown, Matthew Klein, Jack Dobie and Finn Douglas.Biggar beat Kelso - at Hartree Mill. Keith Melbourne scored Kelso’s try which Dwain Paterson converted. Paretson also added a penalty.These results leave Gala in third, five points behind Hariots Blues with two games in hand. Kelso are fourth and Melrose sixth.In National League Two Peebles lost - at home to GHK and in National League Three Berwick lost - away to Howe of Fe.In the Reserve League East One Hawick Force beat Boroughmuir -, Selkirk A lost - to Heriot’s Blues in Edinburgh and Jed-Forest A lost - away to Musselburgh.

title: borders-records-120-coronavirus-case-weekend
story: THE Borders recorded  cases of coronavirus over the weekend, data shows.According to figures released at pm todayby the Scottish Government, between Fridayand today.The total number of cases in the Borders now stands at ,.There are currently  people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed COVID- – a decrease of seven since Friday.The total number of cases in Scotland stands at ,, and there are , in hospital nationally.

title: galashiels-great-tapestry-centre-gets-5-star-visitscotland-rating
story: GALASHIELS’ Great Tapestry centre has been awarded a five-star rating following an inspection from Scotland’s national tourism organisation.The visitor attraction opened its doors to the Borders public back in August.And the centre has now been awarded the highest rating possible from VisitScotland after its first-ever ‘quality assurance’ inspection.Paula Ward, VisitScotland’s regional leadership director, officially presented the five-star visitor attraction status.:Police in Borders warn businesses following recent card machine scamsShe said: “To receive this five-star quality assurance award just a few months after opening is testament to the exceptional visitor experience on offer.“Quality assurance is more than just stars on the door, it is about the entire visitor experience. Our stars represent world class excellence, helping businesses shine, enabling visitors to make informed choices and driving investment in quality.Photo: Phil Wilkinson“The Great Tapestry of Scotland is already one of Scotland’s must-see national visitor attractions and a fantastic example of how tourism really is a force for good, creating wealth and social benefits for businesses and people in the south of Scotland, and enhancing the wellbeing of everyone who visits.”Naomi Harrod, owner of Unwind Yarns in Galashiels, said her store has seen an increase in footfall since the doors of the tapestry centre opened.The brainchild of Alexander McCall Smith, the Great Tapestry of Scotland was hand-stitched by a team of , stitchers from across Scotland, using  linen  and over  miles of wool.:Two arrested in connection with bogus caller incident at home of -year-old manIn addition to the tapestry itself, the centre houses visiting exhibits, a café and workshops.Director Sandy Maxwell-Forbes, who led the development of the new centre, said: “I am absolutely delighted we were awarded five stars from VisitScotland who have helped to create our wonderful new visitor centre..remove“I am incredibly proud of all that we have achieved and continue to achieve, particularly amidst a global pandemic.”Photo: Phil WilkinsonConservative Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine – the council’s executive member for wellbeing, sport and culture – added: “Accolades like this five-star rating do wonders to help promote the national signicance of this visitor attraction across the country and places Galashiels firmly on the map.“This national recognition can act as a springboard for further tourism to the local area and the wider region through  and beyond, providing wide-ranging benefits to businesses and communities alike.”The Great Tapestry of Scotland is operated by Live Borders, which manages many of the cultural and leisure facilities in the region.

title: aldi-launches-valentines-day-inspired-candle-range
story: Love is in the air and to celebrate Aldihas launched a new range of Valentines Day-inspired candles.The discount supermarket is known for being similar to Jo Malones home fragrances but without the hefty price tag. The Hotel Collectioncomes in both candles and reed dfusers starting at £..Each candle is £ cheaper than the Jo Maloneequivalents and burns for  hours. The collections are available to buy in-store from Sunday, February ." alt"Border :Aldi has launched a new collection of Valentines Day-inspired candles and dfusers " class"editor-image"Aldi has launched a new collection of Valentines Day-inspired candles and dfusersHere is everything in the Aldi Valentines Day collection The Hotel Collection Centrepiece Candles come in two light, floral scents: Red Roses and Paris Blossoms and are just £. for g.The Hotel Collection XL Reed Dfuserscome in matching scents and are £. for ml. Scentscerity LED Light Up Candlecomes in glamourous rose gold or deep romantic red and is the perfect gt for those who want to get something extra special, for just £..Finally, there is the Hotel Collection Votive Candle Gt Setwhich includes a duo set of romantic red votives, along with  tealights in ravishing scents of either red rose or peony for £..

title: round-shopping-nearest-pound-tesco-charities
story: SHOPPERS in Galashiels are being encouraged to help support an in-store fundraising campaign for three of the UK’s leading health charities.Last year Tescos ‘Helping you to live healthier’ campaign raised more than £ million after customers rounded up their shop to the nearest £ at self-service tills.Money raised will help Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK to continue their vital work to improve and save lives.As the charities fight back from the impact of the COVID- pandemic, Galashiels shoppers are once again being urged to round up their shopping to the nearest £ at self-service tills between  January and  February.Oonagh Turnbull, Head of Health Campaigns at Tesco, thanked Tesco shoppers in Galashiels for their generosity, which will make a signicant dference to many people’s lives.“The funds raised will continue to support the health of UK communities at such a critical time. Our health charity partners rely on donations to continue their awareness, prevention and research work.”The campaign is part of the Health Charity Partnership between Tesco, Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK. It is an ongoing initiative aimed at inspiring and supporting Tesco colleagues, customers and their families to make healthier food choices and live healthier lives.On behalf of the Health Charity Partnership, Caro Evans, Director of Partnerships at Cancer Research UK, said: “We’re delighted once again to be teaming up with Tesco to raise funds for research and for the vital support our charities provide."Cancer, heart and circulatory diseases, or diabetes affect nearly all of us so by working alongside Tesco we aim to empower millions of people to make healthier choices that can help lower their risk of these conditions."As always, we want to say a huge thank you to Tesco colleagues and customers in Galashiels for their support. With your help we can continue our work and continue to tackle some of the UK’s biggest health challenges.”

title: a7-close-overnight-resurfacing-works-next-month
story: THE A will close overnight next month to allow for resurfacing work south of Ashkirk.The  metre stretch of the A between Selkirk and Hawick will be closed from .pm on Monday, February  until am on February .Diversion routes will be signposted via the A, A and A.These ersions will add approximately  miles and  minutes to journeys.:Coronavirus: Borders records more than  cases over weekend, data showsTommy Deans, BEAR Scotland’s South East Network Manager, said: “These surfacing improvements will help to address the defects on this section of the A, creating smoother and safer journeys for motorists.“It is essential for safety that we close the road during these works. We thank motorists and the local community in advance for their patience and understanding.”Local access will be maintained for residents between the closure points when safe to pass through the works area. Emergency services will have access at all times.For updates and real time information, visit www.trafficscotland.org, twitter at @trafficscotland or the mobile site my.trafficscotland.org

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-watch
story: Nicola Sturgeon is set to give her weekly Covid update in parliament today.Final restrictions put in place in response to the Omicron iant sweeping across Scotland were removed on Monday .In an update last week, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced that nightclubs would be able to reopen, and caps on indoor events and table service requirements where alcohol is served would be removed.These measures were put in place in December, alongside a maximum capacity of  people for outdoor events. This was eased on January .However, the requirements for face coverings and self-isolation will remain for the foreseeable future.: Nicola Sturgeon’s Covid update today as less restrictive framework plannedChanges to #coronavirusrestrictions from  January:🔹 End to m distancing and table service in hospitality🔹 Nightclubs in Scotland can re-open🔹 Non-professional indoor contact sports can resume🔹 No attendance limits at indoor eventsMore ➡️ https:t.co IhaJOcfqJhpic gcHXLwMt— Scottish GovernmentJanuary , In today’s update, the First Minister is expected to discuss a framework for the country as we learn to adapt and manage Covid-.When is Nicola Sturgeon’s next Covid update Nicola Sturgeon is due to give a Covid update on Tuesday, January . This will take place at the usual time of pm.How to watch Nicola Sturgeon’s next Covid update You can watch the Covid update on the Scottish Parliament TV website here.It will also be live streamed across the Scottish Parliament social media accounts, including Facebookand Twitter.

title: scotlands-world-cup-hopes-given-unexpected-boost
story: SCOTLANDS hopes of joining Australia, Wales and hosts New Zealand in Group A of the Women’s Rugby World Cup have been given an unexpected boost following the withdrawal of Samoa and Hong Kong from the tournament.A combination of lockdown restrictions in Hong Kong and challenges regarding re-entry into Samoa which includes a six-monthmoratorium for anyone who tests positive outside of the country meant that both teams are presently unable to travel to Dubai.Bryan Easson’s Scotland side reached the Final Qualication Tournament by finishing second in the European qualying tournament, beating Ireland in a nail-biting last game thanks to late try from Borderer Chloe Rollie.As the top ranked team, Scotland will now only need to play in the final match of the tournament on Friday  February .They will face the winner of Kazakhstan v Colombia, with the semi-final taking place on Saturday  February .The games will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.The Scots have not qualied for the World Cup since .World Rugby Chairman, Sir Bill Beaumont, said: “Our thoughts go out to the players and management who have worked tirelessly in preparation for this tournament and we would like to reassure them that every avenue was explored in attempt to find a solution to this unique and challenging situation.“The health and wellbeing of players, staff and spectators continues to be our number one priority as we continue to navigate the dynamic and complex nature of the ongoing COVID- pandemic. In collaboration with both Samoa and Hong Kong rugby unions, taking the appropriate measures that mitigate the spread of COVID- in line with the relevant authorities is paramount and has underpinned our decision making throughout the duration of the pandemic thus far.“We remain committed to delivering a safe Final Qualication Tournament for the remaining participating unions and will be working closely with Hong Kong and Samoa to ensure the best-possible  campaign for their women’s s teams.”.removeThe finals are scheduled to take place from  October until  November .

title: coronavirus-borders-records-new-cases-24-hour-period
story: FORTY cases of coronavirus have been recorded in the Borders in the last  hours, the latest figures show.The Scottish Government published updated statistics at pm today .And the data shows that the region has now seen , cases of COVID- since March last year.There are  people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of coronavirus, according to the figures – two more than yesterday.The total number of cases in Scotland now stands at ,,.

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-tariff-rates-proposed
story: TARIFF rates for charging electric vehicles in the region have been put forward by Scottish Borders Council .Elected members of the local authority are expected to back the proposals at a meeting on Thursday .Electric vehicle drivers had been able to charge for free due to Transport Scotland funding aimed at encouraging uptake of environmentally-friendly cars.According to SBC papers, rates at p per kWh for ‘journey ’ charge points and p per kWh for ‘all other ’ charge points are being proposed.:Borders woman who admitted drink-driving offence banned from road for  monthsThe report states: “There is currently no dedicated SBC revenue or capital budget allocated to EV infrastructure and any repairs that need to be carried out require to be assessed and funded along with other competing priorities from the ‘street lighting’ budget. Over the last two years £,. has been spent repairing chargers that were faulty. This is projected to increase as chargers progress further into their service le.”The report continues: “The proposal dferentiates between ‘journey’ and ‘destination’ chargers due to journey chargers being signicantly more expensive to purchase and maintain while also aligning closely with neighbouring authorities to provide a level of continuity.“The proposed pricing structure will encourage people who have the ability to charge at home to do so while also helping to ease pressure on the public charging network.“It will also help to create an environment that encourages commercial operators to invest in the installation of charging infrastructure within the Scottish Borders.:‘Must-see’ Great Tapestry centre receives -star rating from VisitScotland“Based on usage figures for  this gives a potential income in the region of £, a year, creating a surplus of around £, a year to contribute towards maintaining the current infrastructure..remove“This excludes overstay charges which would also generate additional surplus and would also allow scope to absorb any small increases in energy prices without the need to constantly alter the tarf.”Journey chargers can supply up to kW alternating current and up to kW direct current, can provide a full charge in around  minutes and are typically used to aid onward travel.Meanwhile, destination chargers y in charging time depending on the size of the charger, .kW units are used for overnight charging and .kW units typically take six to eight hours to fully charge a vehicle.If approved, SBC’s regime will see the introduction of an overstay charge, a minimum charge of £ per session and a p connection surcharge between pm-pm to ease demand on the electricity grid at peak times.:Coronavirus: Borders recorded  cases in last day, figures showSBC’s plans fall in line with schemes currently in place in East Lothian and Midlothian.In Dumfries  Galloway it costs p per kWh for all chargers, with a £. minimum charge.SBC currently has  chargers across  dferent towns and villages, of which the majority are rapid.Gordon Edgar – executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport – told a November meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was £,.A feasibility study has been commissioned to undertake a “region-wide, cross-sector assessment of supply, demand and commercial opportunities to create a strategic delivery model for EV charging infrastructure”.The work is expected to finish in .

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-say-today-face-masks-working-home
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeonhas given give her weekly Covid update in parliament today.The final restrictions that were put in place in response to the Omicron iantwere removed on Monday, January .In an update last week the First Minister announced that nightclubs would be able to reopen, and caps on indoor events and table service requirements where alcohol is served would be removed.These measures were put in place in December, alongside a maximum capacity of  people for outdoor events. This was eased on January .Changes to #coronavirusrestrictions from  January:🔹 End to m distancing and table service in hospitality🔹 Nightclubs in Scotland can re-open🔹 Non-professional indoor contact sports can resume🔹 No attendance limits at indoor eventsMore ➡️ https:t.co IhaJOcfqJhpic gcHXLwMt— Scottish GovernmentJanuary , However, the requirements for face coveringsand self-isolation will remain for the foreseeable future.Heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons briefing today.Working from HomeThe current guidance from working from home has been updated.Nicola Sturgeon revealed that employers can start preparing for a "phasedfrom the office" to a "hybrid working model".This means that you can work some time in the office and work sometimes at home rather than a full .One metre social distancing re-introducedNicola Sturgeon has said a requirement for two-metre physical distancing in settings where face coverings are exempt is being reduced to one metre.The change will apply to settings such as religious services and those carrying out receptionist duties.Updating MSPs, the First Minister also announced a change affecting organised activities for children.She said: “From Friday, face coverings will no longer be required for any adult taking part in organised activities when they are directly interacting with children under the age of five.”.removeInternational travelScotlands international travel rules have been brought in line with the rest of the UK. From February , vaccinated travellers will no longer need to take a PCR test when they arrive back in Scotland. However, vaccinated travellers will need to fill in a passenger locator form.Unvaccinated travellers will need to take a pre-departure test two days before travelling and two days after they arrive back in Scotland. Currently, the international " fully vaccinated" definition includes two doses of the Covid vaccine and not the booster dose. However, this is being kept under review. Ms Sturgeon warned that travel restrictions could be reintroduced in light of a new iant so this is constantly being monitored. Mask wearing in schoolsMs Sturgeon has been facing renewed calls to remove the requirement for mask-wearing in Scottish schools.Masks are no longer needed in English secondary schools with the requirement being dropped from Thursday  January.Face coverings will no longer need to be worn by adults who are leading activities in childcare and early learning settings with children under  years old. Mask wearing restrictions will be changing in schools due to the increase in cases for this age group but the advice will be kept under "close and regular review".Strategic framework The First Minister was expected to outline a strategic framework or  roadmap to move the country to a “less restrictive” society.Ms Strugeon has confirmed that a full outline will be available in the coming weeks. Distance Aware SchemeNicola Sturgeon has encouraged Scots to take note of the Scottish Government’s Distance Aware scheme.The First Minister said badges and lanyards with the Distance Aware logo, indicating the wearer would like extra space, would be available to anyone who wants one.She said: “Soyou or anyone you know is worried about being out and about and would feel safer with a bit more space, please get a Distance Aware badge.“And for everyone ,you see someone wearing the badge or lanyard, give them the space and consideration that they are asking for.”Latest casesNicola Sturgeon also updated the Scottish parliament over the latest Covid cases. While the First Minister said that cases remain high, we are starting to see a "broadly positive picture"., new cases of COVID- reportedhave been reported as well as  new reported deaths of people who have tested positiveThere were  people in intensive care on Monday, January  with recently confirmed COVID- and , people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID-.Ms Sturgeon also noted that cases among under  years old are on the rise which is why the mask wearing in schools restriction has not been removed.The First Minister admitted that this has been the "toughest winter that the NHS has ever faced" and we should remain cautious.

title: sigrid-announces-uk-tour---full-list-venues-dates-get-tickets
story: Norwegian pop sensation Sigrid is hitting the road in  with a UK and Europe wide headline tour.Sigridhas risen through the charts in the past few years with her standout single Don’t Kill my Vibe and globally acclaimed debut album Sucker Punch.Sigridwill be performing throughout the U.K. kicking off in Liverpoolin Autumn with stops in Cardf, Birmingham, Edinburgh, Newcastle, Manchester, London, and Dublin.Heres everything you need to know about tickets and the full list of venues on Sigrids tour.How to get tickets Tickets for Sigrids UK and Europe wide tourwill go on general sale from Friday, January , at am viaLiveNation.Sigrids  UK tour datesUniversity Mountford Hall, Liverpool- Friday, November ,       Great Hall, Cardf- Saturday, November ,    O Academy, Birmingham- Sunday, November ,       Usher Hall, Edinburgh- Tuesday, November ,                   O City Hall, Newcastle- Wednesday, November ,   O Apollo, Manchester- Thursday, November ,     The SSE Arena, Wembley, London- Saturday, November ,     Arena, Dublin- Thursday, November ,

title: aldi-heated-dressing-gowns-blankets-sale---offer
story: Aldiis here to save the day in the cold weather with its range of heated blankets, dressing gowns and more. The discount supermarket has launched a very popular range of heated loungewear and throwsto keep you warm on winter nights. The items are available both online and in-store,but its best to be quick as some items have already sold out on the website. Prices start at £., so you dont have to break the bank.: Aldi launches Valentines Day inspired candle range:Aldis popular outdoor log burner is back - but be quick!Here are all the items available in the range:Dual Heated Under-BlanketDouble price: £. King price: £. Take the edge off those chilly nights with the help of a heated blanket with two remotes for two separate temperature zones and six temperature settings.Set this up - minutes before bedtime, and the warm air will be trapped between your mattress and quilt.The blanket connects to the mains and is machine washable.  Available to order online only from the Aldi website. Heated neck wrapThis fleece neck wrapis microwaveable and perfect for helping with any pain or discomfort. It also gives off a relaxing lavender scent and comes in two colors.Available for £. in-store and online via the Aldi website." alt"Border : Aldis heated range is available in-store and online " class"editor-image"Aldis heated range is available in-store and onlineKirkton House Heated CoatThis comfy heated coatnot only provides warmth but looks great too. The coat has nine temperature settings and can be heated for up to  minutes. It plugs into the power source and can be put in the washing machine. This is currently sold out onlinebut is available in-store from January  for £.. Kirkton House Heated ThrowKeep warm with this doubled-layered heated blanket,which includes a feet pocket. It has nine temperature levels and nine timer steps, which can be controlled by a digital controller.Buy onlineand in-store for £..

title: coronavirus-borders-map-shows-areas-cases-recently
story: A MAP shows which areas of the Borders have seen the most new cases of coronavirus in recent days.The interactive Public Health Scotland tool also shows the positive case rate per , of the population.The map – which splits the Borders into  neighbourhoods – is based on figures recorded between January -.According to the data, Tweeddale West Area has had the most new cases of COVID-, seeing .:Borders man who spat on police officer warned he could face prison sentenceTweeddale East Area and Cheviot East recorded the next highest number of cases – with  and  respectively.Meanwhile, Langlee’s  cases gives the area a seven-day rate of . per , – the highest in the Borders.Tweeddale West Area , Kelso Southand Cheviot Eastall recorded rates of more than , placing them in the highest category.At the other end of the scale, Hawick’s ‘North’ and ‘West End’ areas recorded fewer than three cases during the seven days, putting them in the lowest category for rates.To see the map, click hereand then select ‘cases by neighbourhood’.

title: borderers-celebrate-burns-wreath-laying-ceremony
story: MEMBERS of the Gala Burns Club celebrated Robert Burns at the weekend with a wreath laying ceremony in the town.Gathering at Lawyer’s Brae on Saturday , a group of club members came together to celebrate the Bard after their Burns’ Supper on Friday was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.“COVID had taken the decision [to cancel] for us,” said Gala Burns Club president Bruce Robertson.And at the wreath laying ceremony members were treated to a poetry recitation by -year-old Nicole Dalgleish and piping from Angus Campbell who won the Robert Burns World Federation Cup in bagpiping in .Looking to the future, Mr Robertson says the club has plans to hold a social event for members later in the year.He said: “We’re hoping to organise a social event in early April or May.“Not a supper but a gathering.“But it depends on the COVID situation.“It’s on the books for the near future to get members back for a social evening to help keep Burns alive in Galashiels.”

title: hammer-recommends-lowland-league-young-players
story: FORMER Gala Fairydean Rovers player Jamie Gullan is looking forward to lining up in front of , fans at Celtic Park next month in the fth round of the Scottish Cup.And the -year-old believes that his loan spell at Netherdale has contributed to his progress in the game.Nicknamed ‘The Hammer’ by fans and team mates the player joined Hibernian in  after starting in the Hearts youth system.He quickly progressed through the Academy ranks scoring one of the goals in the final as Hibs beat Aberdeen to win the – Scottish Youth Cup.In  he joined Gala Fairydean Rovers after impressing in a - victory for the Edinburgh side in a friendly at Netherdale.And he enjoyed a successful spell in the Borders under Steve Noble, scoring three-goals for the club.Gullan is now encouraging other young players to follow in his footsteps, although not in his boots!Jamie told the Border : “Joining Gala was a good learning curve and dferent to being about the Hibs training centre but I enjoyed it. It was a really good first taste of men’s football which was physical and tough, and I improved because of that."I played up front with Stuart Noble and learned a lot from him and others in the team, including not to wear pink boots. We had a good dressing room and I still keep in touch with some of the players and keep an eye on the scores.“I’d play for Gala on the Saturday and then play for the Hibs reserves in midweek, so I got plenty of game time. Gala are a fantastic club and everyone made me feel very welcome from the beginning."I would definitely recommend going on loan to the Lowland League to all youngsters trying to make the grade. Because Rangers and Celtic are in it now, the league has a much higher profile.”After ing to Hibs, Neil Lennon gave him his first-team debut against Faroese club NSI Runavik in the Europa League qualiers in July  and since then he featured in  games, scoring three goals, all of them in cup competitions..removeHis first was in a - victory over Inverness Caledonian Thistle in the quarter-final of the Scottish Cup but just as he was starting to become a regular in the first-team, COVID struck and football was suspended before ing without fans.Earlier this month he joined Championship side Raith Rovers for an undisclosed fee having played with the Fe side on-loan on three occasions.

title: greens-announce-candidate-gala-ahead-council-election
story: THE Scottish Borders Green Party has announced its candidate for the Galashiels and District ward at this year’s council elections.Fty-five-year-old Neil MacKinnon will contest the ward at the elections set to be held in May.This will be the first time the father of three has stood in an election, however, he has worked with previous Scottish Green Party campaigns.Mr MacKinnon says he is ‘honoured’ to have been selected to represent the Scottish Borders Greens.He said: “I am honoured to have been chosen for this role and hope to be elected so I can serve the people of Galashiels.“With the climate emergency a real and present danger it is important to elect Green politicians to every level of government to help drive the change that is required to meet this emergency head on.“No action by any council or inidual is too small not to count.”Mr MacKinnon, who is originally from Peebles but has lived in Galashiels for most of his le, says one of his goals is to encourage the use of ‘micro-generation projects’ in the town, as well as across the region. Another is to see a greater roll-out of electric vehicles.He said: “The council should be encouraging micro-generation projects, solar and small-scale wind on public buildings like village halls and libraries.“The privately funded river turbine at Philiphaugh should be a model for the council to promote the use of the fast flowing rivers in most Borders towns as a reliable and sustainable source of power.”The scientic equipment engineer added: “Many people in the region, especially in Galashiels, live in accommodation where charging an electric vehicle is just not possible. There needs to be a drive for on-street charging points in residential areas through the Borders.”Mr MacKinnon is joined by Dominic Ashmole who will stand for the Scottish Borders Greens in the Tweeddale West ward in the May elections.

title: a68-reopens-directions-overturned-vehicle-incident
story: THE A has reopened in both directions following an accident involving an “overturned vehicle”, according to road officials.The route had been shut between Carter Bar and Otterburn, with ato “normal traffic conditions” not expected until around .pm.However, a Traffic Scotland spokesperson confirmed that the road has now reopened following the removal of debris from the carriageway.Urging to pass with caution, the spokesperson added: “The vehicles involved are still in the location – recovery is on the way.”More updates to follow

story: Have the January blues got the better of you  Fear not, easyJet has launched a payday saleso you can escape the winter weather and jet off., seats are reduced in the sale, starting from £. – including over the February half term!This follows the news that restriction free travel for UK arrivals is set to resume with testing requirements being removed for travellers in time for the February holidaysThe sale covers travelfrom February  until September , .For those looking for a package getaway, you can save £ on a holiday with a minimum spend of £, £ off holidays with a minimum spend of £ and £ on a minimum spend of £.
