title: fundraising bolsters plans for portree play
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe plan to develop a new asset for the community in Matheson Place will cost £, and is being led by a sub-group of the Portree and Braes Community Trust headed up by local resident Tfany Maberley.Ms Maberley has two sons, who are now teenagers, but speaking to the Free Press this week, she explained her motivation for taking on the venture.She said: “My sons are  and , so people might wonder why I am doing this. “But I have always been involved in helping with things to do with the kids around here and I usually raise money for the young carers each year.“Six months ago, I was visiting a friend in Glasgow. She#s in Cruickston # there is quite a big estate there and when I went for a walk there, I came across a park almost every minute of the walk. I was amazed how many there were there.“I put up a post about this on Facebook # as the two parks we have in Portree are not really looked after and are quite dilapidated.“I asked why we can’t do better for our kids here. It started a big conversation and got loads of people talking about it. Lots of parks were mentioned where local groups had got together to develop them, like the one in Plockton and the one in Kyleakin.”Tfany was given a helping hand by friend Gary Shinnie who suggested the old park in Matheson Place, which had been left to rot, and agreed to assemble a squad of volunteers to help clear the site.After chatting to Highland Councillor John Gordon, Drew Millar from the local community council, and the Portree and Braes Community Trust, and a representative from the Lochalsh and Skye Housing Association it was decided that the best way for Tfany to take the project forward would be through the Trust’s Outdoor Activity group.The project was able to acquire £, from the National Lottery, and the group raised £,. last Friday and Saturday at the Co-op in Portree.Commenting on the response, Tfany said: #Friday and Saturday wasn#t just about fundraising it was also about making people aware of the project.“When people were standing and put their signatures down, we were able to explain to them what we were doing, and when they saw the plans, most people said that it was a great idea, and they loved the fact that it had things for children with special needs in it.”The group is raising money through funding applications, a JustGiving page, and is also inviting businesses to get involved in supporting the project too.A D plan of the play park has been made by Kompan, who also worked on the new playpark in Kyleakin.The park will comprise  dferent play activities including four swings, an octopus seesaw, a carousel, a four-tower unit with a tunnel and a slide, it will be able to accommodate  users of all ages.Although there’s still plenty to do to bring the play park to le, Tfany is confident that it will happen, and this year.to donate to project.

title: dreuchd ur ann an
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineADVERTISING FEATURE: NEW YEAR, NEW CAREERAig an àm seo den bhliadhna, bidh sinn tric a’ smaoineachadh air ar dreuchdan atharrachadh agus mar sin is dòcha gum bi an goireas ùr aig Bòrd na Gàidhlig feumail dhuibh ma tha sibh a’ beachdachadh air dreuchd ùr ann an teagasg tro mheadhan na Gàidhlig.’S e goireas didseatach a th’ ann am padlet far a bheil làraich-lìn, sgrìobhainnean agus bhideothan air an cruinneachadh air balla. Lorgair na slighean eadar-dhealaichte a-steach gu teagasg sa Ghàidhlig, agus tha e na amas gum bi seo na dhòigh tharraingeach dha daoine am fiosrachadh a tha a dhìth orra gus gluasad gu teagasg sa Ghàidhlig fhaighinn gu sgiobalta.Tha padlet ann gus stiùireadh a thoirt do thidsearan clàraichte a tha airson an sgilean cànain a leasachadh gus gluasad gu Foghlam tro Mheadhan na Gàidhlig agus padlet eile dhaibhsan a tha a’ beachdachadh air cùrsa Foghlam Gàidhlig a dhèanamh aig ìre fo-cheum no iar-cheum.Gheibh sibh a-steach dhan phadlet le bhith a’ sganadh an còd QR no theirigibh gu gaidhlig.scot ga foghlam fiosrachadh-as-uirePadlets have been created to present the dferent pathways into teaching in Gaelic, with information for both registered teachers wishing to develop their language skills to teach in Gaelic and students considering an undergraduate or postgraduate Gaelic Education course.Access the padlet by scanning the QR code with your device or by visiting gaidhlig.scot en education latest-information

title: learning opportunities with west highland college uhi starting in january
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineADVERTISING FEATURE: NEW YEAR, NEW CAREERWe are part of the University of the Highlands and Islands, one of the UK’s newest and most exciting universities providing access to world class education in the Highlands and Islands. With ten college centres you’re never too far away from West Highland College UHI.We have full time Countryside Skills with Ranger Training in Fort William and Maritime with Aquaculture in Mallaig and Transition to Further Education available in any location, all starting in January. Or perhaps you would be interested in starting a career in care with a brand new, six-week, Introduction to Care course you can study from anywhere. We also have a wide range of options in cookery, hospitality, the creative arts, social care, creative computing or administration – so get in touch, we#ll have something for you.“I completed my degree in Sculpture at Grays School of Art then did a Masters in Fine Art at Edinburgh College of Art. Because sculpture is my speciality, I am excited about our new part time sculpture course. Students will get the chance to experiment with a iety of materials, clay, plaster, wire and found objects, working on projects and exploring expressive drawing to develop ideas. Sketchbook work will be developed with ideas further explored and refined. I really hope newcomers will join us to explore this accessible and creative art form.”“The focus of Countryside Skills with Ranger Training was preparing for real le jobs with training and industry links which are missing in typical academic focused degrees. We covered so much ground and learned with experienced practitioners. I would recommend the course to anyone interested in wildle and the conservation sector. I have recently accepted a permanent job as an assistant warden on the Rhinns of Islay RSPB reserves. To say this is a dream job is an understatement!”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220113newstake part in this year s big garden birdwatch
story: Keep your eyes wide open, get the kettle on and grab your binoculars as RSPB NI encourage you to join in on the charity’s Big Garden Birdwatch this month. That’s right, registration is now open for the world’s largest garden wildle survey taking place th- th January , and you don’t even have to leave your home to be part of it. RSPB NI is asking the public of Northern Ireland to spend just one hour watching and recording the birds in their garden, balcony or local park, then send their results to the RSPB. Over a million people took part in , counting  million birds – making it the biggest Birdwatch ever! By taking part in the Birdwatch, you will be helping to build an annual snapshot of how birdle is doing across the UK. It is only by understanding how wildle is faring that we can protect it. So, what are you waiting for  Take action to help solve the problems facing nature! To take part in the Big Garden Birdwatch  and receive your FREE Big Garden Birdwatch guide, which includes a bird identication chart, top tips for your birdwatch, plus advice on how to help you attract wildle to your garden, text BIRD to  or visit www.rspb.org.uk birdwatch

title: history made at kells connor wi
story: Kells  Connor WI made history in  when their AGM was held in a cattle shed , courtesy of the McAllister family.New President, Rosemary McAllister and her Committee members were elected including Anna Murphy , Eleanor Worthington , Helen Mitchell , Jill Crockard , Wilma Buick , Mary Crothers  Gwen Henson , Olga O’Neill  Iris Manson , Angela Currieand Sharon Graham The competition winners for the Bell Challenge Cup were: st – Maura Ellis, nd – Angela Currie and joint rd Sally Harper  Rosemary Farquhar.Maura Ellis spoke about her avid crafting interests and showed some of the wonderful exhibits made the talented Kells  Connor WI craftswomen.The ladies subsequently attended their annual Christmas dinner in the more luxurious surroundings of the Rosspark Hotel, where they enjoyed a delicious meal and held a quiz afterwards. The competition was ‘A mask with a dference’, which was split into two groups due to the response. ‘Covid’ mask results were: st Sally Harper, nd May McDowell and rd Eleanor Worthington. ‘Other’ mask results were: st Marilyn Barr, nd Maura Ellis and rd Mary Crothers.A very special presentation took place when six long-standing members were awarded honorary membership – Marjorie McDowell , Sally Harper, Margaret McKay, Margaret McIlveen, Margaret Erwin and Ruby McSeveney. They were each presented with a yellow rose, symbolising friendship, by Rosemary McAllister on behalf of the Committee.Congratulations were extended to two ladies who had ‘special’ birthdays - Carol Adams and Elizabeth Brown.The December meeting took the form of a Christmas party held in St. Saviour’s Church Hall. Various forms of entertainment were provided including Dingbats and a quiz, organised by Olga O’Neill and Iris Manson, a sketch by Marie Mewha and Eleanor Worthington and a selection of poems by Rosemary McAllister and Wilma Buick. The competition was a handmade Christmas bauble. Winners were: st Jean McKee, nd Mary Crothers, rd Sharon Graham.A beautul selection of hampers were won by: Vonla Allen, Jean Crawford, Jill Crockard, Iris Fullerton, Pearl Hanna, Beth MCaughern, Rosie McIlfatrick and Vivien Mawhiney. Other foodie goodies were won by: Carol Adams, Rose Allen, Lynne Francey, Sally Harper, Eleanor Lorimer, Rosemary McAllister, Marjorie McDowell, Olga O’Neill, Helen Mitchell and Jenner Smith. Two new members have also been warmly welcomed – Muriel Cupples and Carolyn Wilson, so a great start to the new WI calendar year thus far.

Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownHealthCoronavirusBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Covid impact on our clubs has been ‘catastrophic’, says Belfast promoterAs restrictions are eased, Joe Dougan says it will take a long time for entertainment venues across NI to recover Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseClub and events promoter Joe Dougan FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueClub and events promoter Joe DouganMaureen ColemanTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe impact of the pandemic on entertainment venues has been ‘catastrophic’ and will take a long time to recover from, a Belfast club and events promoter has said.According to Joe Dougan, nightclubs such as The Limelight have been closed for  weeks over the past two years and only fully opened for eight.Read MoreHands up: Fteen NI venues back open this week for party-goersHe said that due to the fast-changing restrictions and ious closures and reopenings, many people were unaware of theof time that entertainment venues had been out of business and that the road to recovery would be a long and challenging one.But he said he was hopeful the demand for club nights and concerts was still there and that it wouldto business as usual as consumer confidence started to pick up again.Joe was speaking as nightclubs across Northern Ireland prepared to reopen today at noon as part of a series of relaxations to the current restrictions.The latest changes follow on from Boxing Day last month when rules around table service in bars and restaurants were tightened and nightclubs were closed due to the Omicron iant.From noon today, nightclubs can reopen, with dancing and indoor standing events also able to resume. Covid passports will no longer be legally required in bars, restaurants and cinemas but will still be needed to gain access to a club or to indoor unseated or partially seated events with  people or more.On Tuesday the Department of Health recorded , positive cases of Covid and five deaths in the past  hours.Joe said he hoped that an Executive meeting on February  would remove mandatory Covid certication in all settings to bring nightclubs and other entertainment venues into line with the rest of hospitality.And he said nightclubs had suffered more than any other hospitality setting throughout the pandemic. “It’s coming up to two years since restrictions were introduced and as of today, we’ve been closed for  weeks and open for eight,” he said.“It’s not commonly understood just how catastrophic restrictions have been for us. There have been so many dferent permutations of reopening, that people are confused by it all.“If, for example, you attended a seated concert or a comedy or magic show and wanted to stand up or dance, that hasn’t been possible for  weeks.“Without clarity, we’ve lost access to touring events. A band or DJ touring England and thinking about adding a show in Ireland is faced with a tough decisionnot sure what the rules are orthey might change at any minute.“Anyone who plays to a standing or partially standing audience might then prioritise where, so that’s been very dficult.” Joe said that while it was harder to arrange gigs hastily following last-minute lting of restrictions, the demand for nightclubs was still evidently there, particularly among students. Club nights at The Limelight are selling out fast from Wednesday through to the weekend and staff are gearing up for a busy period ahead. But he’s in no doubt about the upcoming challenges for the sector.“Hopefully this is the end of the restrictions and we can get back to planning and back to business,” he said.“But it’s going to take a long time to fully recover from the damage for many sectors including hospitality, retail and travel.”At the Kremlin nightclub, a deep clean of the premises was under way ahead of reopening and staff were brought in to ensure the sound and light systems were ready for Wednesday night.Allen Gordon said the last reopening had been ‘phenomenal’ and that he was expecting an even better turnout this time around.And he said he was hopeful for the future of the nightclub.“There has been a fantastic reaction on social media to the reopening of the club and we’re expecting a big crowd down come the weekend,” he said.“The response was phenomenal the last time we reopened and we’re expecting an even better reaction this time.“It’s been a dficult time with all the closures and reopenings but it looks like we’re coming out of it now and I don’t think this will happen again, all these restrictions being put in place.“Here’s hoping we’re at the tail end of it, plus we’re coming into the better weather. People want out.“The reopening of nightclubs is a much-needed boost for hospitality.”Most ReadDoors close on Windsor Presbyterian ChurchMan who died in Carrickfergus crash incident named locally as John TraynorMichelle O’Neill says historical tweets by Sinn Fein politicians ‘not acceptable’ as three MLAs issue apologiesIn Pictures: Bloody Sunday... images from the BelfastarchivesQuiet man: Sue Gray’s country singer husband prefers to let his music do the talkingTop VideosPlayVideo: School bully is knocked out after trying to punch a blind kid - title: doors close on windsor presbyterian church
story: Emotional farewell: Windsor Presbyterian Church in south Belfast first opened its doors in  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEmotional farewell: Windsor Presbyterian Church in south Belfast first opened its doors in Alf McCrearyEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA church in Belfast which opened  years ago will close its doors this Sunday at the end of its morning service.Windsor Presbyterian’s congregation will then walk down to their new home at Great Victoria Street Presbyterian Church, near the city centre.Rev Ivan Steen, the minister since , said: “We are leaving Windsor because the stonework on this late th century building has deteriorated so much that we cannot afford to fix it. The building is being taken over by an art and drama group which, I believe, will have access to the required funding for a proper refurbishment.“We regard this as an exciting opportunity to literally move on to a site nearer the city centre, and we are most grateful that the Great Victoria Street Church is giving us such a warm welcome.“Our closing service this Sunday will include a number of special guests including several of our former ministers, and the Presbyterian Moderator, the Right Reverend Dr Bruce. It will certainly be a landmark occasion, and for some people an emotional occasion as well.”Over the years Windsor church, on the corner of the Lisburn Road and Derryvolgie Avenue, amalgamated with others in the South Belfast Presbytery. In  it merged with the former Broadway Presbyterian Church on the Falls Road, which is now an Irish Language Centre. Recently the Windsor members shared an Irish language service of worship at the centre.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Then in , Windsor amalgamated with Ulsterville Presbyterian Church on the Lisburn Road. Cecil Graham, a longtime Presbyterian and elder at Windsor said: “In  in response to the increasing number of immigrants coming to Belfast, the South Belfast Presbytery in partnership with the Council for Mission in Ireland established the International Meeting Point project on the Lisburn Road.“Partnership with the IMP has been instrumental in reviving the Windsor congregation, and many of its members attend our Sunday services.” In its heyday, Windsor was one of the most fashionable and influential Presbyterian churches in Ireland. Two of its ministers became moderators — Rev John Irwin in  and Rev William Corkey in . The Corkey family in particular made a signicant contribution to the wider work of the Church, including the establishment of Adelaide House and other care homes.Windsor church has also made an important contribution to the Mission Outreach of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, and particularly in China and India. During the Second World War, Windsor missionaries were imprisonment by the Japanese.It has had eight ministers in its history, including Rev Steen.The church is on the list of buildings of special architectural or historic interest. It was designed in  by the architects Young and MacKenzie who also designed the Robinson and Cleaver building opposite Belfast City Hall.Most ReadDoors close on Windsor Presbyterian ChurchMan who died in Carrickfergus crash incident named locally as John TraynorMichelle O’Neill says historical tweets by Sinn Fein politicians ‘not acceptable’ as three MLAs issue apologiesIn Pictures: Bloody Sunday... images from the BelfastarchivesQuiet man: Sue Gray’s country singer husband prefers to let his music do the talkingTop VideosPlayVideo: School bully is knocked out after trying to punch a blind kid - title: ni council considers poover deployment to tackle dog fouling
story: New measures are being considered to tackle dog fouling FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNew measures are being considered to tackle dog foulingBy Adam Morton, Local Democracy ReporterJanuary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA council in Northern Ireland is considering deploying a ‘poover’ to help tackle the dog fouling pandemic that has beset the borough.The issue was raised at Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council on Monday by Councillor Darryn Causby.He called foul on the council for failing to get on top of the issue of dog excrement which has become widespread across the borough.“I do not want to get into a whole debate about it but one of the issues we always face as councillors is that when there are issues around dog fouling we have to speak officers to try and get them out to clean it,” he said.“I happened to notice the other day that Belfast City Council have a machine called Fido which, pardon the pun, effectively acts as a ‘poover’.“It is a cart with a suction device attached that will essentially clean dog foul off the streets.“I have been inundated with complaints about this issue and want to propose that Council looks at it through the environmental services committee. We should consider putting the machine on the capital services list for expenditure or at least come up with some way to protect out employees.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “I am conscious some staff are having to get down and lt it themselves. There are other health and safety issues as well, particularly in relation to children across parks and round by schools and quite often at the end of garden paths.“Hopefully it can be brought back through committee with a report detailing what Belfast are doing and there experience.”Sinn Fein councillor Keith Haughian seconded the proposal and called for an innovative approach to be taken to tackle the problem.“I would wholeheartedly second the proposal that more is brought to committee. This issue is not going away, in fact it is getting worse and that is a reflection on us as a council,” he said.“We need to be asking other areas what they are doing and to come up with better ideas.“It is fair to say although there is a lot of stuff that can ide us in this chamber, all of us will be united when it comes to these issues. When I speak to Alderman Stephen Moutray we can do nothing but agree that the dog fouling issue just seems to get worse and worse.“It is a timely proposal in a sense. As we move towards the end of the pandemic, we can’t just go back to what we did before and hope that it works, we need to be more innovative so I am happy to second the proposal from Councillor Causby.”Lord Mayor Glenn Barr noted there has been a “massive rise” in dog ownership throughout the borough recently.Councillor Kyle Savage noted it is not just the urban centres where the issue of dog fouling is a problem.“The rural areas of Waringstown and Dollingstown are feeling it too. There is one lady I know has lted  bags of dog poo, that is not acceptable it is not the dogs it is the irresponsible dog owners we need to be looking at,” he said.“I agree with the two councillors before me we need to be looking at other areas of good practice and seeing what we can do to improve but it really lies with the dog owner.“There are perhaps not enough people on the ground but it is totally irresponsible, dog owners need to wise up and clean up after themselves.”Noting the problem is just as bad in Rathfriland as it is in Banbridge, Lurgan and Portadown, Councillor Paul Greenfield said he believes the problem is “getting worse”.Thanking Mr Causby for bringing the proposal forward, Councillor Declan McAlinden said dog fouling in rural areas has become “absolutely ridiculous”.“We all see the figures for our town centres, but we need to see them for rural areas as well,” he said.“Rural roads at the minute are a disgrace and recently I was driving past a local school and the youngsters were having to step over dog foul outside the school, it is absolutely ridiculous.”With the proposal receiving the support of the chamber, officers will now draft and present a report on the issue to Council’s environmental services committee as soon as possible.Most ReadDoors close on Windsor Presbyterian ChurchMan who died in Carrickfergus crash incident named locally as John TraynorMichelle O’Neill says historical tweets by Sinn Fein politicians ‘not acceptable’ as three MLAs issue apologiesIn Pictures: Bloody Sunday... images from the BelfastarchivesQuiet man: Sue Gray’s country singer husband prefers to let his music do the talkingTop VideosPlayVideo: School bully is knocked out after trying to punch a blind kid - title: ni water advises to check toilets for leaks on thomas crapper day
story: NI Water has advised people to check their toilets for leaks FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNI Water has advised people to check their toilets for leaksEimear McGovernTwitterEmailJanuary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailNI Water has advised customers to checktheir loo is leaking to celebrate Thomas Crapper Day in honour of the man who invented the toilet.An English businessman and plumber, Thomas Crapper died in  after having made the humble toilet a feature in households and pioneering the ballcock within the toilet cistern - which is why a day in his honour is celebrated on January .But toilets can sometimes leak and NI Water said this can waste around  to  litres of water through constant leakage from the cistern into the pan.That’s approximately . –  bath tubs, or enough water for up to seven loads of washing.It#s become an issue recently because of a change in design of toilets to dual flush with non-visible audible internal overflows, along with more households replacing their water systems to mains-fed bathrooms which increases water pressure.John Mulgrave, Water Regulations Field Manager at NI Water said: “The world has changed dramatically since Thomas Crapper was alive, but there are many problems he would recognise immediately.“One in  households have a leaky loo and yet they often go unnoticed. The leak could look minimal, and some people may even think this is a design feature to keep the toilet bowl fresh.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “The worst of leaking toilets can waste up to , litres a day – which is equivalent to  bath tubs! It’s easy enough to checkyou have a leak andyou do, it’s easy to repair.”NI Water has produced a checklist which will help establisha toilet is leaking.If you can hear a flow of water when the toilet hasn’t been flushed or can see a slight but constant trickle at the back of the toilet pan, you may have a leaky loo.Wait until half an hour after the last flush then wipe the back of the pan dry with toilet tissue. Then place a new, dry sheet of toilet tissue across the back of the pan. Leave it in place for up to three hours without using the toilet . If the paper is wet or torn in the morning, you know you have a leaky loo.A free LeakyLoo strip can also be ordered by visiting www.savewatersavemoney and entering your postcode.If you have a leak they normally are pretty straight forward for an approved plumber or keen DIY-er to fix, either by adjusting or replacing the bits inside a cistern with new parts. It#s advised that the new parts are compliant with the water fittings regulations. To do this, and to search for an approved plumbing business near you go to www.watersafe.org.ukMost ReadDoors close on Windsor Presbyterian ChurchMan who died in Carrickfergus crash incident named locally as John TraynorMichelle O’Neill says historical tweets by Sinn Fein politicians ‘not acceptable’ as three MLAs issue apologiesIn Pictures: Bloody Sunday... images from the BelfastarchivesQuiet man: Sue Gray’s country singer husband prefers to let his music do the talkingTop VideosPlayVideo: School bully is knocked out after trying to punch a blind kid - SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium People who retweeted Poots post may be suedDefamation action: lawyers for DUP man and we to launch Twitter trawlExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDUP Minister for Agriculture Edwin Poots FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDUP Minister for Agriculture Edwin PootsAllison MorrisTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailLawyers acting for Edwin Poots and his we are to examine Twitter accounts for anyone who may have retweeted a sexist joke posted by UUP leader Doug Beattie.The DUP Agriculture Minister has instructed solicitors to issue defamation proceedings against Mr Beattie and Tory MP Simon Hoare over an offensive tweet concerning the DUP politician and his we.Read MoreEdwin Poots issues defamation proceedings against Doug Beattie and Tory MP Simon Hoare over offensive tweet about his weMr Beattie posted the tweet on Saturday evening, but later deleted it and apologised after a backlash on social media.However, at that stage it had already been retweeted a number of times.It made a reference to Mr Poots, his we and a brothel.Among those to retweet the offensive post was Mr Hoare, who is chairman of the Northern Ireland Affairs Committee at Westminster.Solicitors acting for Mr Poots and his we Glynis are examining the accounts of other Twitter users to seethey are to be included in the defamation proceedings.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up In a precedent setting  High Court case, Tory peer Lord McAlpine was successful in defamation proceedings against users who retweeted untrue allegations of child sex abuse.Among those who had to pay out were Sally Bercow, we of then Commons Speaker John Bercow, and the comedian Alan Davies.Lord McAlpine’s legal counsel said at the time the latter’s “reckless retweet” of a defamatory statement “fanned the work of internet trolls”.Lord McAlpine initiated, or at least threatened, legal action against  Twitter users, with it being accepted by the court that the retweeting of a libel was actionable.Mr Beattie is still in his job despite dozens of other derogatory messages dating back to  coming to light, some containing racist, misogynist and Islamophobic slurs, as well as offensive posts about the Traveller community.On the same day the Poots tweet was posted, an opinion poll for the Belfasthad him as the most popular party leader.He has since said the posts were “pretty horric” and he was “deeply ashamed” of them.However, he denied he was a racist or a misogynist.Mr Beattie insisted the tweets were “not who I am”.Mrs Poots, a Sunday school teacher, has always shunned the limelight.She was said to be deeply upset by the Ulster Unionist leader’s post.Mr Poots originally said he accepted Mr Beattie’s apology, but he questioned his “poor” judgment in posting it in the first place.But now it has been confirmed that he is taking legal action over the post.Patrick Higgins, from solicitors Donnelly and Wall, said yesterday: “Today we instigated proceedings on behalf or Mrs and Mr Poots against Mr Beattie MLA and Mr Hoare MP who published this tweet.“This post constitutes a grave and unwarranted attack on my clients’ reputation.“As a couple of  years, married for , it has caused my clients profound distress.“As a lady who has recently retired after dedicating her le as a nurse to caring for terminally ill children, it is wholly inappropriate for any persons to make such comments, and the publication has caused immense hurt to her, her husband and their family.”Following a meeting of Ulster Unionist MLAs and party officers yesterday, it was announced Mr Beattie would remain as leader.He said: “I have had detailed conversations with all of my MLAs, I apologised for what I had done directly to each one of them, and then I spoke [about] whether or not I still had their support to remain as party leader — overwhelmingly, every one of them said ‘yes, I did’.”While there has been no public statement from senior elected members, some of the party’s junior members have come out in support.Kate Evans, who works in Mr Beattie’s constituency office, posted online that she had worked for the Upper Bann MLA for six years, adding: “I wouldn’t be the person I am todayit weren’t for his support and encouragement over those years as I recovered from domestic violence.“I don’t recognise the man in those tweets.“I accept his apology and I support him.”Julie-Anne Corr-Johnson, who joined the UUP last year as a North Belfast representative, said: “There is no other leader I trust more with my children’s future than @BeattieDoug.”Bethany Ferris, a party officer, said: “Everyone has a past. This is why I fundamentally believe in judging people for who they are now. @BeattieDoug has always been kind and supportive… I admire him for taking responsibility for his past and trust him to lead our party into the future.”Most ReadDoors close on Windsor Presbyterian ChurchMan who died in Carrickfergus crash incident named locally as John TraynorMichelle O’Neill says historical tweets by Sinn Fein politicians ‘not acceptable’ as three MLAs issue apologiesQuiet man: Sue Gray’s country singer husband prefers to let his music do the talkingIn Pictures: Bloody Sunday... images from the BelfastarchivesTop VideosPlayVideo: School bully is knocked out after trying to punch a blind kid - title: prime minister under pressure to explain role in afghan animal airlift
story: Puppy Seble was rescued by Nowzad  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePuppy Seble was rescued by Nowzad By Geraldine Scott and Patrick Daly, PA Political StaffJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailBoris Johnson is coming under increasing pressure to explain his role in the evacuation of animals from Afghanistan amid reports he did influence their removal from Kabul – despite his denials.No  has repeatedly said Mr Johnson had no involvement in pushing for help for the charity Nowzad, after accusations that officials’ time was taken up supporting the charity rather than people who could have been brought to the UK.Leaked emails surfaced on Wednesday in which Foreign Office officials suggest the Prime Minister “authorised” their rescue, despite Mr Johnson previously saying it was “complete nonsense” that he had intervened."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ba .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ba .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ba .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ba .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Prime Minister Boris Johnson rides in the back seat of a Government car PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePrime Minister Boris Johnson rides in the back seat of a Government car And Sky News reported that Conservative MP Trudy Harrison, who was then parliamentary private secretaryto Mr Johnson, had contacted a private charter company to try to secure a plane to help with the Nowzad evacuation, and a source at the company told the broadcaster it was implicit that she was acting with the PM’s backing.Ms Harrison previously wrote to former Royal Marine Paul “Pen” Farthing, who ran the Nowzad shelter, to inform him the evacuation would go ahead.She told Sky News on Wednesday that she had contacted companies, and had told staff she was a PPS to Mr Johnson, but that she was acting as a constituency MP and Mr Johnson was not involved in plans around the evacuation.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace, in his second comment on the situation in a matter of hours, said the Nowzad evacuation was “nothing to do with the Prime Minister”.Documents released by the Foreign Affairs Select Committee overnight showed how Sir Philip Barton – the Foreign Office’s permanent-under secretary – said he was “not aware” of support for the decision to evacuate Nowzad either in No  or from the Prime Minister.He said that “beyond speculation in the public domain” he did not know of any reason civil servants would attribute the decision to the PM."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Jake Berry defended the PM PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJake Berry defended the PM Conservative MP Jake Berry told the BBC’s Newsnight programme that junior staff may have played up No ’s involvement.He said that “junior officials in Government departments or officials in Government departments often” would put across “the views of Downing Street or No  without in truth knowing whether it’s correct”.Earlier, the Defence Secretary told broadcasters: “The claims that have been made and emails from the Foreign Office, who were not responsible for the actual evacuation operation, I don’t know where they come from but they certainly don’t show the reality, which was: I was in charge, the Prime Minister never asked me, it was nonsense.”No  also issued a statement, coming shortly after the Prime Minister’s official spokesman held a briefing with reporters, stressing that Mr Johnson had played “no role” in the UK armed forces rescue mission, Operation Pitting, or the evacuation of animals from the Taliban-captured territory.Mr Farthing launched a high-profile campaign to get his staff and animals out of Afghanistan after the fall of Kabul, using a plane funded through donations.The UK Government sponsored clearance for the charter flight, leading to allegations that animals had been prioritised over people in the exit effort."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbce .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbce .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbce .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk fbce .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Pen Farthing was the founder of animal rescue charity Nowzad PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePen Farthing was the founder of animal rescue charity Nowzad The re-emergence of the row comes after a whistleblower leaked email exchanges to the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee, with MPs making them public on Wednesday.The evidence shows an official in the private office of Lord Goldsmith – a joint Foreign Office and environment minister – told colleagues working on the evacuation on August  that “the PM has just authorised their staff and animals to be evacuated”, in reference to the charity Nowzad.Lord Goldsmith tweeted: “I did not authorise and do not support anything that would have put animals’ lives ahead of peoples’.“My position, which I made clear publicly, was that the UK should prioritise evacuating people.“I never discussed the Nowzad charity or their efforts to evacuate animals with the PM.”The email was handed to the committee by Raphael Marshall, who worked for the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Officeat the time, and has claimed the animals were evacuated following a direct instruction from the Prime Minister.Dominic Dyer, who led the political lobbying campaign from the UK for Nowzad to be offered support, said Mr Johnson’s refusal to acknowledge his role in the evacuation had “tarnished” the campaign.Mr Dyer said the published emails “vindicated” what he had previously set out, and argued the Prime Minister could be “very proud of giving support to this as a humanitarian rescue mission”.He told the PA news agency: “I’m not certain why he didn’t feel he could explain his involvement in August at the end of this operation.“It has tarnished what has been a very important operation that had huge public support.”He told Sky News: “I know Trudy Harrison, the PPS to the Prime Minister that was helping us on the campaign team, reached out to the CEO of Virgin Atlantic, and we were just looking at dferent options that were available to us.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ce .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ce .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ce .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ce .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_aebcb--cd-bb-ec_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Trudy Harrison PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTrudy Harrison Opposition parties said the email disclosure to MPs indicated the “Prime Minister has been caught out lying” and accused him of making the “wrong calls”.
